review_text: One of the good science planetariums in Bangalore. And many science experiments kept at out side of the building, and no maintenance and 70% experiments were damaged/not working The weekend is fully crowded. The ticket is 70 adults and 50 for the above 3year kids. Mini snacks shop is available inside the campus, sky theatre is good to understand about the planet, there is no real telescope to see the planet.

Good explanation about ISRO & its success. The 180¬∞  theatre experience was also good

Guys this is basically a spherical theatre. I haven't been to such a place before. They play a space information documentary for about 45 minutes. Very cool place and one of a kind experience. The images of interactive things are from the outside and not the main attraction.

Please keep in mind this has slots for English and Kannada. Please book tickets in advance if possible. The 75 rs ticket is primarily for the theatre.

The documentary briefly covers the growth in knowledge about space from geocentric theory to theory of relativity, gravitation lensing, red shift and blue shift. If you've completed 10+2 with PCM you won't get any new information. However, the experience is truly worth it.

Feedback for owners: the documentary is kind of old and the editing is outdated. Please modernize it. It would be awesome.

It is a must visit place in Bengaluru. It's a very calm and peaceful place for spending time with family, kids and friends. It's located in a large area with a lot of greenery surrounded by it. There is a playground for children as well with some swing and other play equipment. There are some trees and flower plants with a neatly maintained lawn.

There are many real size replicas of Military tanks, Helicopter, Jet, Ship replicas, Missiles displayed in the park and maintained properly. The park also consists of a military Museum which is not functional now.
There we can see many Soldiers' names who sacrifice their life for the nation engraved in the walls. There is a Monumental Stone with a National Flag adjacent to it.
Indira Gandhi Musical fountain is another attraction of the park. The water light show is in the evening with 2 shows lasting half an hour each.

The National Military Memorial Park in Bengaluru stands as a dignified tribute to the valor and sacrifice of the Indian Armed Forces. Located adjacent to the Indira Gandhi Musical Fountain Park, this park is a poignant reminder of the bravery and dedication of the soldiers who have served the nation.

The park is thoughtfully designed with a central focus on the memorial, which includes an imposing granite structure and an eternal flame that burns in honor of fallen soldiers. The layout is simple yet powerful, with well-maintained lawns and pathways that create a peaceful environment for reflection.

The park features several monuments and exhibits that highlight the history and achievements of the Indian military. Plaques with names of martyrs, detailed descriptions of various battles, and displays of military equipment provide an educational experience for visitors. The prominent Victory War Memorial is a focal point, offering an inspiring sight that instills a sense of pride and respect for the armed forces.
The park is well-maintained, with clean pathways and ample seating areas where visitors can sit and reflect. Informative plaques and signs help visitors understand the significance of the various monuments and exhibits.

The National Military Memorial Park in Bengaluru is a significant and moving tribute to India's military heroes. Its serene environment, educational exhibits, and respectful design make it a must-visit for anyone wishing to pay homage to the brave soldiers of India. While there is room for enhancing the visitor experience with more interactive elements and amenities, the park's core purpose of honoring the military is beautifully achieved.

Waow.. Excellent place to see Indain Fighter, Missiles, Tank, etc. If you want to see the real Tank, come here. If you want to see the real Jet fighter, come here. If you want to see the real touch of Agni missile, Akash missile, Prithvi Missile, Pinaka missile. You can come and see here. The place is quite large and big. It is very peaceful and clean. You will see the names of Indian fighter who brings glorious to our country. Take a time to visit the park for sure.

The trees are beautiful, and I love the shadows they cast. There's also a very big Indian flag at the top. If you enjoyed my review, please like it!

My visit to The National Gallery of Modern Art was truly a peaceful and enriching experience. The gallery‚Äôs calm ambiance allowed me to fully immerse myself in the world of modern art. One of the highlights of my visit was exploring the incredible artwork by Mr. JMS Mani. His art pieces beautifully capture the essence of life's journey and his unique perspective. It was fascinating to learn about his artistic evolution and the depth behind his work. The gallery is a perfect blend of culture, history, and creativity, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking to explore the beauty of modern art. A memorable experience that left me inspired!

Loved the serene and tranquil environment of this place in the midst of the busy city. The beautiful trees, shrubs and flower plants adds to the beauty of the place. The entry ticket fee for Indians is Rs 20 which is nominal. After entering, there is a store where you will have to keep your bags (if any) and collect the token. The main art gallery is housed inside an old age building. The pieces of art and sculptures are incredible and captivating. The ground floor houses the artworks of the famous Nandalal Bose. The above two floors houses a lot of attention seeking paintings including acrylic, water color, oil, mixed color, ink and pencil sketch paintings to name a few. The design of the building and the overall maintenance deserves appreciation. Also liked the polite gesture of the staff. A lift facility is available. An auditorium, washrooms and a cafeteria are present on the ground floor. I had a wonderful experience while visiting here. I would highly recommend paying a visit here once.

Good place for art lovers and culture enthusiasts. It features a good collection of traditional and contemporary art, including folk art, Mysore paintings, and modern works by renowned artists.
Regular art exhibitions, flea markets, and cultural festivals happens every week. Exhibition stalls offer unique handmade crafts, brass items, jewelry, and paintings,  souvenirs or gifts. A must visit place. There is canteen within the premises.  Has ample parking space Check their schedule for exhibitions and events before visiting

Karnataka Chitrakala Parishath is a true haven for art lovers and culture enthusiasts. The sprawling campus is not just a gallery but a vibrant cultural hub. It features an impressive collection of traditional and contemporary art, including folk art, Mysore paintings, and modern works by renowned artists.

The regular art exhibitions, flea markets, and cultural festivals bring the place alive and offer something new every time you visit. The serene atmosphere amidst greenery makes it an ideal spot to explore creativity or simply unwind.

The small art shops and stalls offer unique handmade crafts, jewelry, and paintings, making it perfect for souvenirs or gifts. A must-visit for anyone in Bangalore who appreciates art, culture, or just a peaceful day out.

Tip: Check their schedule for exhibitions and events before you go to make the most of your visit.

Amazing artistic place, best for the people who has keen interest in Art. They exhibit the paintings which is truly amazing to watch it and enjoy the experience.
Really a good place and they do have variety of things to purchase which makes difficult to choose among the collections.

The vibe of the whole place is so serene that it‚Äôs completely worthy of spending a whole afternoon on a Sunday. Four galleries are there, come, enjoy the paintings, know about your contemporary artists. Shop different states artisans craft from the alley. Buy original artist works from art mart. Have a nice snack and coffee from the canteen. Seat under the age old baniyan tree. Breathe the same air as all the other eminent artists since 1960s.

I really loved this place.... it's so good to be here. It's all about arts and art enthusiastic people should check this place out. It's an art gallery and a museum where you can see different varieties of art forms. There is more to learn about art. They have their own small canteen also outside this place and many people come here over the weekend. Outside this place they have art exhibition going on which is a 10 days program where people from different different state comes with their stalls to sell their products and you can stop there to buy something. This place was so peace to me personally I liked it and I will definitely go again.

Overall, the art festival was a feast for the senses and a testament to the power of art in bringing people together. It‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone who appreciates creativity and culture. I left feeling inspired and look forward to attending again next year!

We visited Karnataka Chitrakala Parishath on January 26th, and it was an absolute treat for art lovers. The vibrant atmosphere, coupled with the ongoing Kala Dwani event, made the experience even more special. The campus was buzzing with creativity, featuring stunning artworks, live performances, and a deep celebration of Indian culture.

One of the highlights was the Craft India Exhibition, which showcased an exquisite collection of handcrafted products from artisans across the country. From intricate textiles and traditional paintings to beautiful pottery and jewelry, the exhibition truly reflected the rich heritage of Indian craftsmanship. The dedication of these artisans was evident in every piece, making it a great place to appreciate and support handmade art.

The overall ambiance of Chitrakala Parishath, with its lush greenery and heritage-rich galleries, added to the charm. Whether you‚Äôre an art enthusiast or just someone looking for an inspiring outing, this place is a must-visit!
Absolutely loved the Art Exhibition and the Haat Bazaar. Paintings were really beautiful and well arranged. Each painting had an information with it so that you can directly contact the artist.

Good place to visit. Meditation inside the pyramid was wonderful and impactful.
There is a small library inside the pyramid and shopping area. A place to spend time wisely. There is lot of green area where children could enjoy playing and kayaking in a small pond is also good.
They provide free lunch from 12:30 PM to 2PM everyday unfortunately I could not taste as I was late. There is a paid cafeteria with a limited menu even.
There are no charges except for parking, 50 for car and 20 for bike. There are some adventure activities where families can spend a full day while engaging in activities and roaming leisurely.
The only drawback is the road around 1km near the location is full of potholes and parking space needs to be levelled and improved.

"Pyramid Valley International is a serene and peaceful retreat that offers a unique blend of natural beauty, spirituality, and wellness. Nestled in a tranquil setting, this haven provides the perfect environment for relaxation, meditation, and rejuvenation.

The meditation and yoga sessions are truly uplifting, and the peaceful ambiance creates an ideal atmosphere for introspection and self-discovery. The natural surroundings, complete with lush greenery and soothing sounds of nature, further enhance the experience.

One of the standout features of Pyramid Valley International is the complimentary food service, which offers delicious and nutritious meals that cater to diverse dietary needs. The food is prepared with love and care, and the hospitality is warm and welcoming.

The staff is friendly and supportive, ensuring that guests feel comfortable and at ease. The facilities are well-maintained, and the overall experience is truly rejuvenating.

*Rating*

- Ambiance: 5/5
- Food: 5/5
- Service: 5/5
- Meditation and Yoga: 5/5

*Recommendation*

Pyramid Valley International is perfect for:

- Those seeking a peaceful retreat from city life
- Individuals looking for spiritual growth and self-discovery
- Nature lovers and outdoor enthusiasts
- Anyone seeking relaxation, meditation, and wellness programs

A truly wonderful place to unwind, recharge, and connect with nature and oneself!"

Nestled amidst lush greenery, this tranquil haven offers a perfect retreat from the noise of everyday life. The air is fresh, the atmosphere calm, and the surroundings filled with natural beauty that soothes the soul. Ideal for meditation and inner reflection, the serene ambiance helps one reconnect with peace and stillness. Visitors are welcomed with warmth and offered wholesome, satwik meals‚Äîboth breakfast and lunch‚Äîentirely free of cost, making the experience not just enriching but also deeply nourishing in every way.

You can spend a couple of hours exploring the place and also set aside some time for meditation. There are also paid activities like kayaking if you're interested.
In Bangalore, it's one of the nice weekend spots to visit‚Äîjust keep your expectations realistic!

If you're looking for a place to completely disconnect and just breathe, Pyramid Valley on Kanakapura Road is that spot. It‚Äôs calm, super peaceful, and honestly gives you the kind of inner peace that you don‚Äôt even know you needed until you're there.

The whole vibe is very zen ‚Äî perfect if you're into spirituality, mindful living, or just trying to be more present and connected with yourself and your surroundings. Like, if you're in your healing era or just need to escape the chaos, this is a solid reset.

The main pyramid is HUGE and lowkey magical. Not even kidding ‚Äî you can literally feel the energy shift the moment you walk in. It‚Äôs quiet, still, and just makes you want to sit down and breathe. Super powerful experience, especially if you're into meditation or want to give it a try.

The place is surrounded by greenery, tall trees, and there‚Äôs even a little lake. They have other fun stuff too like paddling, archery, and off-road biking, so it‚Äôs not just all spiritual and serious ‚Äî you can chill and have fun too. Total balance.

They also run meditation sessions all day long, from sunrise to sunset, and they‚Äôre actually so calming. You can do guided meditations, join their programs, or just sit alone and vibe ‚Äî no pressure at all. It‚Äôs also spiritual in a very open, non-religious kind of way, which is honestly refreshing.

Bonus points: there's no entry fee (just pay for parking), and they even serve free lunch, which is such a sweet gesture. There are also cafes and canteens if you wanna buy snacks or coffee. You can either stay the day or book a stay for a few days if you really wanna dive in deep.

Whether you're going solo for some introspection, or with your fav people to share the energy ‚Äî it‚Äôs an amazing space. Super grounding, super healing. 100% recommend if you‚Äôre on your self-awareness journey or just want a break from the usual routine.

Good peaceful experience of the meditation centre. The approach road from the highway to this place is not so great. Once you're inside it is very peaceful. The meditation centre has timings for different type of meditation like silence meditation, music meditation etc. make sure you choose the silent meditation. It has got some powerful vibes inside. Visited the Shrungagiri Sri Shanmukha Swami Gudi, and it was a peaceful and divine experience. The temple's unique architecture with six faces of Lord Shanmukha (Murugan/Karthik) is truly amazing. The atmosphere was calm, and the view from the top was beautiful, specially at the evening. A must-visit place for spiritual seekers and architecture lovers in Bengaluru.
The temple is usually open from 6:30 AM to 12:30 PM and 4:30 PM to 9:00 PM, so plan accordingly. Evenings are ideal as you can enjoy the serene atmosphere and beautiful lighting on the temple.
There are some stairs to climb, but it‚Äôs not too hard, and the view from the top is worth it.
The main sanctum is stunning, and there‚Äôs a beautiful collection of idols(lord ganesha and many others) inside that you shouldn‚Äôt miss.
As you climb the stairs, there‚Äôs a artificial cave and Siva Linga in the middle, which is a lovely spot to stop and pray.
You need to leave your shoes outside with a nominal price(3/-).
There‚Äôs parking available, but it can get crowded during weekends or festivals, and if u want to reach by BMTC bus, u have to reach at Arehalli/BEML Layout bus stop from there it's around 1.5km/1km walking(use google map).

Shrungagiri Sri Shanmukha Swami Gudi

Shrungagiri Sri Shanmukha Swami Temple, located in Rajarajeshwari Nagar, Bangalore, is a magnificent and serene spiritual destination dedicated to Lord Shanmukha (Lord Murugan). The temple is renowned for its unique architecture, which features a grand six-faced dome symbolizing Lord Shanmukha's six faces, with the structure beautifully designed to reflect divinity and artistic brilliance.

Perched on a hill, the temple offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding areas, creating a peaceful and spiritual ambiance. The intricate carvings, vibrant sculptures, and serene environment make it a must-visit for devotees and tourists alike.

The temple is not just a place of worship but also a center for cultural and spiritual activities. Special poojas and festivals like Skanda Shashti and Thai Poosam are celebrated with great devotion and grandeur, attracting thousands of devotees.

Visiting Shrungagiri Sri Shanmukha Swami Gudi provides a blissful experience of spirituality, devotion, and architectural splendor. Don‚Äôt miss the opportunity to seek blessings and soak in the tranquil atmosphere of this divine destination.

A Divine and Architectural Marvel

Shrungagiri Sri Shanmukha Temple in Rajarajeshwari Nagar, Bengaluru, is a must-visit spiritual and architectural wonder. The temple, dedicated to Lord Shanmukha (Murugan), stands atop a hill, offering breathtaking views and a peaceful atmosphere.

The highlight of the temple is its six-faced gopuram, symbolizing the divine attributes of Lord Muruga, and the stunning crystal dome that illuminates in beautiful colors at night. The temple also features a unique Ganesha idol collection, showcasing over 1,000 forms of Lord Ganesha.

The climb to the temple involves around 150-200 steps, but the serene surroundings and divine energy make it a rewarding experience. The temple is well-maintained, clean, and peaceful, making it ideal for meditation and spiritual reflection.

Timings: 7:30 AM ‚Äì 12:30 PM & 4:30 PM ‚Äì 9:00 PM.
Best time to visit: Early mornings for a tranquil experience or evenings for the mesmerizing lighting effects.

Highly recommended for devotees and tourists alike!

This is an amazing Roman Catholic Basilica/church in Shivaji Nagar area in Bangalore dedicated to Mother Mary.

The original church was built by Tamil Christian‚Äôs settlers in 17th century. It was later reconstructed by French Missionaries in 1875.

The church is built in Gothic Style Architecture with Towering spires, arched windows, large pillars and intricate stained glass artwork

Basilica houses a 6 foot tall statue of Mother Mary.  Statue is dressed in a Saree to symbolise the cultural blend of Christian and Indian traditions.

This church is elevated to Minor Basilica status in 1974 by Pope Paul VI and the first one in Karnataka.

St. Mary‚Äôs feast is celebrated in September which attracts thousands of devotees across India.

The premises houses, an adoration chapel, reconciliation centre, religious articles shop, parish priest‚Äôs office/residence and a marriage hall beside a flag mast and a row of statues of saints.

There‚Äôs very little to no parking space available, need to park on the Shivaji Nagar bus stand side or near Russel market. All roads leading to church are congested, occupied by road side vendors selling all sorts of things. Constant horn sounds and tourists chatting makes the place noisy.

I visited the ISKCON Temple in Bangalore recently, and it was a truly peaceful and refreshing experience. There‚Äôs also a gift shop and a museum with displays about Krishna‚Äôs life, which I found really interesting. Even if you‚Äôre not very religious, the peaceful energy and scenic surroundings make it worth a visit.

It‚Äôs a great place to spend some quiet time, reflect, or just enjoy the positive vibe. I left the temple feeling mentally relaxed and spiritually refreshed. If you‚Äôre in Bangalore, I‚Äôd definitely recommend visiting at least once.

Every corner of ISKCON Vaikuntha Hill showcases thoughtful planning and meticulous execution, making it a must-visit landmark for anyone seeking architectural brilliance intertwined with divine serenity. A true marvel and a blessing to witness!

place_name: SRI BIG BULL TEMPLE (Shri Doddabasavanna Temple)
review_text:
The Big Bull Temple, also known as Dodda Basavana Gudi, is a serene and historic site located in Basavanagudi, Bengaluru.
It houses a massive monolithic statue of Nandi, the sacred bull of Lord Shiva, carved from a single granite rock.
The temple's peaceful atmosphere and traditional Dravidian architecture attract devotees and tourists alike.
Surrounded by Bugle Rock Park, it offers a calm, green space for relaxation and reflection.
Early mornings and evenings are ideal for visits, especially during the annual groundnut fair, "Kadalekai Parishe."
Overall, it's a spiritual and cultural gem in the heart of the city, worth a calm and mindful visit.

place_name: SRI BIG BULL TEMPLE (Shri Doddabasavanna Temple)
review_text:
The Big Bull Temple in Basavanagudi is a must-visit for anyone seeking a blend of history, culture, and tranquility. The temple is home to a stunning bull sculpture, which stands as a testament to its rich history dating back to the 16th century. With its roots connected to Nadaprabhu Kempegowda, the founder of Bengaluru, the temple holds a special place in the city's heritage.

What makes this temple experience even more enriching is the thoughtful display of its history outside, offering visitors a chance to learn about its fascinating past. The temple also shares its premises with the famous Dodda Ganapathi Temple, just a short 50-step walk away, making it convenient to explore both in one visit.

The atmosphere around the temple is peaceful, with a lush green garden adorned with intricately carved statues representing cultural diversity. If you're visiting in November, don't miss the renowned Kadlekayi Parishe (Groundnut Fair), a vibrant event held during Kaarthika Maasa, which adds a festive charm to the temple's serene environment.

Overall, the Big Bull Temple is a wonderful spot to experience spirituality, history, and a peaceful atmosphere, making it one of Bengaluru's cultural gems.

place_name: SRI BIG BULL TEMPLE (Shri Doddabasavanna Temple)
review_text:
The Bull Temple in Bangalore, also known as the Nandi Temple, has long been on my list of places to visit, and I finally had the opportunity to explore it last weekend. Nestled in a peaceful corner of the city.

The temple is renowned for its massive statue of Nandi, the sacred bull that is closely associated with Lord Shiva. The sheer size of the idol is awe-inspiring, measuring about 4.6 meters in height and 6.1 meters in length, making it one of the largest Nandi statues in the world. It‚Äôs truly a sight to behold, and standing in front of it, you can‚Äôt help but feel a sense of reverence and wonder.

I visited the temple around 7 PM, and despite it being a weekend, the atmosphere was wonderfully peaceful and not too crowded. This allowed me to fully appreciate the beauty and tranquility of the surroundings without being rushed.

I highly recommend visiting this gem of Bangalore, especially if you‚Äôre seeking a quiet escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Jamia Masjid in Bangalore is a magnificent testament to Islamic architecture and spirituality. The mosque's grand fa√ßade, adorned with towering minarets and intricate domes, immediately captivates visitors. Inside, the serene atmosphere, complemented by cool marble floors and gentle lighting from chandeliers, offers a tranquil space for prayer and reflection. Its capacity to accommodate up to 10,000 worshippers underscores its significance in the community. Beyond its architectural beauty, Jamia Masjid stands as a cultural landmark, inviting both devotees and tourists to experience its historical and spiritual essence.

It's a peaceful and beautifully designed mosque located in the center the city. The architecture is impressive, with intricate details and a calm atmosphere that offers a perfect place for prayer and reflection. It‚Äôs well-maintained and welcomes visitors respectfully. A must-visit for anyone interested in history and culture.

It is one of the largest mosques in the city and can accommodate a whopping ten thousand followers at a time. The structure is a 5 storey architectural masterpiece built out of pure white marble from Rajasthan. It is located in the heart of the City Market Area.

I recently visited the Jamia Masjid in Bangalore City and was deeply impressed by its grandeur, serenity, and spiritual ambiance. This magnificent mosque is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking peace, tranquility, and a connection with the divine.

Pros:

- Stunning architecture: The mosque's Mughal-style design, intricate carvings, and ornate minarets are breathtakingly beautiful.
- Peaceful atmosphere: The mosque's vast courtyard and prayer halls exude a sense of calm, making it an ideal spot for reflection and meditation.
- Rich history: Jamia Masjid has a rich cultural and historical significance, dating back to the 19th century.
- Welcoming community: The mosque is open to visitors of all faiths, and the community is warm and welcoming.

Cons: None

Highlights:

- Beautiful architecture and design
- Peaceful and serene atmosphere
- Rich history and cultural significance
- Welcoming community

Overall, Jamia Masjid is a spiritual oasis in the heart of Bangalore City. I highly recommend visiting this magnificent mosque to experience its beauty, tranquility, and warmth.
Jumma arabic sermon khutba starts at 145 pm
An energetic and beautiful atmosphere, a peaceful mosque in the heart / My heart wants me to also serve the society /

This Jamia Masjid is one of the oldest in Bengaluru, near KR Market. This building has impressive facade works and a spherical dome. This place calms me down. I go there quite often on Sundays. I have langar too. I attend the prayers and try to sit there for atleast 2 hours whenever I go. It's a blessing to stay near to such religious places that can heal you. Waheguru üôè ‚Ä¶

Sri Guru Singh Sabha, located near Ulsoor Lake in Bengaluru, is the city's largest Sikh shrine.

Established in 1943 and inaugurated in 1945, this prominent white structure on Kensington Road serves as a central place of worship for the Sikh community.

Everyday, the Gurudwara offers 'Guru Ka Langar,' providing free meals to all visitors. The management also oversees a convention hall and a high school. Visitors can admire the Guru's Takhat and a marble Palki in the spacious prayer hall.

The Gurudwara is easily accessible, with Halasuru metro station nearby.

One of the biggest gurudwara in Bengaluru.
Mesmerising vibes and super spiritual experience.
One can have langar and can contribute in "seva" in any form- cooking, chopping, washing dishes etc.

It's a beautiful Gurudwara Sahib near the ulsoor lake, also known as the Gurudwara Singh Sahib. It's a Sikh worship place. Anybody can come inside, offer prayers, take blessings and eat langar regardless any caste, religion and race. Just don't carry anything like tobacco, alcohol, cigarette or any other drug related stuff. Cover your head before entering and keep it always covered when you are inside.

It's immense pleasure for me to visit this place. Roaming in Bangalore at night coming across with curiosity to see this place it self  a Wonderful experience. The gurudwara of 1948 newly renovated with full of white marble. Very peaceful and langar was very delicious.
Shoe racks are neatly organized, place is very clean in very corner.

Whole building is accessible for disabled people. It have lift, ramps railings, signage facility.  Wheelchair, separate seating to provide comfortable zone for disabled and  senior citizens.

Very humble service from staff and volunteers'. Finally we said sasrikaal.

During the Navaratri festival, the temple is beautifully decorated with different varieties of alankara (adornments), creating a divine and festive atmosphere. The temple is also well-decorated during the jatre (annual fair), making it a wonderful time to visit.

The Banashankari Temple in Bengaluru is a revered spiritual destination with a rich history and cultural significance. Dedicated to Goddess Banashankari, a form of Goddess Parvati, the temple is believed to bring blessings and prosperity to its devotees. The name "Banashankari" originates from "Vana" (forest) and "Shankari" (consort of Lord Shiva), symbolizing the goddess's connection to nature.

The temple's architecture is simple yet captivating, with intricate carvings and a serene ambiance. It is especially vibrant during the annual Banashankari Jatre, a grand festival celebrated with devotion and enthusiasm. The temple premises are well-maintained, and the peaceful environment makes it an ideal place for prayer and reflection.

Located in the heart of Bengaluru, the Banashankari Temple is not just a place of worship but also a cultural landmark that attracts devotees and visitors alike. It‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone seeking spiritual solace and a glimpse into the city's rich heritage.

place_name: Cave temple Shri Gavi Gangadhareshwara Swamy Devasthana
review_text:
The Sri Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple, also known as Gavipuram Cave Temple, is a notable example of Indian rock-cut architecture located in Bengaluru, Karnataka. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple is carved within a natural cave and features impressive monolithic sculptures and pillars. A major attraction is the unique phenomenon of sunlight illuminating the Shiva Linga through the Nandi statue's horns during Makar Sankranti.
The temple was built in a natural cave in Gavipuram and is dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is a fine example of Indian rock-cut architecture, with the temple structure carved out of a single stone. The temple is known for its monolithic pillars and sculptures, including two pillars supporting a giant disk of the sun and moon. The courtyard also features four monolithic pillars representing Damaru and Trishul.
The mysteries of Bengaluru's famed Gavi Gangadhareshwara ...
The temple's architecture is particularly intriguing due to its precise alignment, which allows sunlight to fall directly on the Shiva Linga during specific times of the year, specifically during Makar Sankranti. This phenomenon, known as Surya Majjana, is a major event that attracts thousands of devotees. The temple is a testament to the architectural and astronomical knowledge of ancient India

Divine Vibes on Hanuman Jayanti 2025 ‚Äì A Soul-Stirring Experience at Ragigudda Prasanna Anjaneya Temple, Bengaluru

On the blessed evening of Hanuman Jayanti 2025, I had the divine fortune of visiting the Ragigudda Prasanna Anjaneya Swamy Temple in Bengaluru ‚Äî and what an unforgettable spiritual journey it was!

As the sun dipped and the temple lights began to glow, the entire atmosphere turned ethereal. The vibrant chants of Hanuman Chalisa, the calm yet charged energy of devotees, and the gentle breeze carrying the scent of incense and flowers created a sacred aura that touched the soul deeply.

The temple premises were immaculately managed, with a well-maintained queue system that allowed all devotees to have a peaceful darshan of Lord Hanuman, who stood tall and mighty in his full divine glory. There was a sense of joyful discipline ‚Äî everyone smiling, sharing a common reverence, and waiting their turn with devotion in their hearts.

The prasadam ‚Äî simple yet filled with grace ‚Äî was shared lovingly, and each bite felt like a blessing.

But what truly elevated the experience to a celestial plane was the spectacular Hanuman Dhara waterfall ‚Äî flowing gloriously, illuminated and glistening like a spiritual cascade straight from the heavens. Watching it, surrounded by chants and the temple bells ringing in rhythm, gave me goosebumps. It was not just a sight, but a feeling ‚Äî of being closer to the divine.

On this Hanuman Jayanti, the Ragigudda Temple didn't just host a celebration ‚Äî it gifted a divine experience. I walked out feeling light, blessed, and deeply connected to the divine strength of Lord Hanuman.

Jai Bajrangbali! Jai Ragigudda Anjaneya!

A Hidden Gem Behind the Temple ‚Äì The Majestic Thrimurthi Sculptures

Tucked away behind the bustling sanctum of Ragigudda Sri Prasannanjaneya Swamy Temple lies one of its most serene and spiritually charged highlights‚Äîthe stunning Thrimurthi sculptures. Carved directly into the rock, these larger-than-life depictions of Brahma, Vishnu, and Maheshwara (Shiva) are truly awe-inspiring.

Each of the three deities is sculpted with immense detail and reverence, capturing the essence of the creator, preserver, and destroyer in Hindu philosophy. The peaceful ambiance, combined with the natural rock backdrop and flowing water features, creates a meditative atmosphere that's perfect for reflection and quiet prayer.

This sacred spot often goes unnoticed by hurried visitors, but it's well worth taking the time to pause and absorb the divine presence radiating from these powerful images. Whether you're a devotee, an art enthusiast, or someone seeking tranquility, the Thrimurthi site adds a deep, spiritual layer to the temple experience.

Don't miss it‚Äîthis beautiful rock shrine is a reminder of the timeless nature of Sanatana Dharma and the incredible artistry rooted in Indian temple culture.

Ragigudda Sri Prasanna Anjaneya Temple Review

Nestled on a small hillock in the heart of Jayanagar, Bengaluru, the Ragigudda Sri Prasanna Anjaneya Temple is a peaceful and spiritually uplifting destination. Dedicated to Lord Hanuman (Anjaneya), this temple is not only a place of devotion but also a spot of quiet reflection amid the bustle of the city.

The temple's elevated location provides a great view of the surrounding neighborhood, and climbing the well-maintained steps to reach the sanctum adds to the spiritual experience. The main deity, Lord Hanuman, is powerful and beautifully adorned, inspiring devotion and reverence. The temple complex also houses shrines dedicated to Lord Rama, Sita, Lakshmana, and other deities, adding to the sense of completeness for devotees.

One of the highlights is the massive monolithic idols of Brahma, Vishnu, and Maheshwara, which are carved into a single rock and are truly awe-inspiring. The entire premises are clean, well-managed, and have a calming atmosphere thanks to the greenery and open spaces.

Saturdays, Hanuman Jayanti, and other festival days draw large crowds, and the energy is truly electric during these times. The temple trust also engages in community service and maintains a cultural hall where spiritual discourses and events are held.

Pros:

Clean, serene environment

Stunning rock carvings and idol architecture

Excellent maintenance

Easily accessible within the city

Can get crowded on weekends and festival days

Limited parking during peak hours

Ragigudda is more than just a temple ‚Äî it‚Äôs a blend of devotion, heritage, and calm. Whether you‚Äôre a spiritual seeker or simply someone looking for a peaceful retreat, this temple is definitely worth a visit.

place_name: Shree Parshwa Susheel Dhaam Shwetamber Jain Temple
review_text:
A Divine Experience at Shree Parshwa Susheel Dhaam

I recently had the privilege of attending the Shri Yantra and Chakraraj Pooja at the magnificent Shree Parshwa Susheel Dhaam Shwetamber Jain Temple, located in Attibele, Bengaluru. This temple is a true architectural marvel, constructed entirely from pristine white marble, and exudes an aura of tranquility and devotion.

From the moment I stepped onto the temple grounds, I was enveloped in a sense of peace and spiritual calm. The intricate carvings and the serene environment provided the perfect setting for introspection and prayer. The temple is dedicated to Shankeshwar Parshwanath and also houses idols of Ghantakarna Mahaveer, Padmavati Mata, and Nakoda Bhairav, each radiating divine energy .

The temple complex is thoughtfully designed, featuring a Dharamshala for pilgrims, a Bhojanshala offering pure vegetarian meals, and a playground for children, making it a holistic spiritual retreat for families .

Participating in the pooja amidst such a serene and sacred environment was a truly uplifting experience. The meticulous organization and the devotion of the temple staff added to the sanctity of the event. I left the temple feeling rejuvenated and spiritually enriched.

I highly recommend visiting Shree Parshwa Susheel Dhaam to anyone seeking a peaceful and divine experience. It‚Äôs not just a temple; it‚Äôs a sanctuary for the soul.

Ulsoor Lake, also known as Halasuru Lake, is one of the largest and oldest lakes in Bangalore, covering an area of approximately 123.6 acres. Located in the eastern part of the city near M.G. Road, it is a popular spot for both locals and tourists seeking a peaceful retreat.

The lake features several small islands and is surrounded by lush greenery, making it an ideal location for leisurely walks, picnics, and bird watching. Boating is a popular activity at Ulsoor Lake, with options for paddle boating, row boating, and motor boating available to visitors. The serene waters and scenic surroundings provide a perfect backdrop for relaxation and recreation.

Ulsoor Lake is also home to the historic Sri Someshwara Swamy Temple, adding a cultural and spiritual dimension to the area. The lake's well-maintained walking paths and jogging tracks attract fitness enthusiasts, while its tranquil environment makes it a favored spot for meditation and yoga.

Ulsoor Lake stands as a testament to Bangalore's natural beauty and historical significance.

Nestled in the heart of Mattikere lies a hidden gem: the enchanting park, a haven for nature enthusiasts and families alike. Offering free entry, it welcomes all to indulge in its tranquil beauty and vibrant atmosphere.

Upon entering, visitors are greeted by the serene sight of two picturesque lakes, adding a touch of serenity to the surroundings. The ongoing toy train adds a whimsical charm, delighting both children and adults alike as it winds its way through the park.

For those seeking a leisurely stroll, the sand path and surrounding walking track provide the perfect opportunity to immerse oneself in the lush greenery. The safari ride at Bannerghatta Biological Park was truly the highlight of my visit and an experience I would absolutely recommend to anyone visiting Bangalore.

The ride takes you deep into the forest area of the park, giving you a chance to see wild animals roaming freely in large, natural enclosures ‚Äî way better than watching them behind cages. The thrill of spotting a tiger walking right next to your safari bus or watching a lion resting just a few feet away is something unforgettable.

What I really appreciated was how well-organized the safari was. The forest guides and drivers were very experienced and made sure everyone got to see the animals clearly without disturbing them. The safari covered different zones for herbivores, bears, lions, and tigers ‚Äî each one felt exciting in its own way.

The park maintains a good balance between adventure and safety. The vehicles were sturdy and secure, giving us the freedom to enjoy the wildlife without worry. The entire safari lasted about 45 minutes to an hour, and it was worth every minute.

If you‚Äôre planning to visit Bannerghatta Biological Park, the safari ride is a must-do. I would recommend visiting during weekday mornings to avoid long queues and have a more peaceful experience. Don‚Äôt forget to carry a good camera ‚Äî you‚Äôll definitely want to capture these moments!

I visited Bannerghatta Biological Park on a Sunday, located about 25 km from where I was staying. The roads leading up to the park are generally good, though they become a bit narrow as you approach the entrance. There's a large parking area available, with a one-time parking fee of ‚Çπ50.

From the bus station, it‚Äôs a short walk to the ticketing counter. Entry tickets are priced at ‚Çπ100 per person. Once inside, you have the option of walking or opting for a battery-operated car service, which costs ‚Çπ100 per person. The battery car takes you around various enclosures and waits for all passengers before moving to the next stop. The entire tour takes about 60‚Äì90 minutes and concludes near the bird section, from where you can catch another battery car back.

The park houses a wide variety of animals including lions, tigers, leopards, bears, wolves, wild dogs, hyenas, elephants, deer, giraffes, hippos, crocodiles, monkeys, tortoises, squirrels, snakes, and other reptiles. It‚Äôs a treat for wildlife enthusiasts and families alike.

Outside the park, there are plenty of stalls selling food, toys, beverages, and souvenirs. Local transportation is easily available for your return. Be prepared for heavy crowds on weekends and holidays.

There‚Äôs also a separate Wildlife Safari available for an additional fee, offering a 45-minute tour. Both AC and non-AC buses are offered for the safari.

Overall, it‚Äôs a great place for a weekend getaway with family or friends.

I recently visited the Dodda Alada Mara in Bengaluru, and I was thoroughly impressed!

This sprawling banyan tree, estimated to be over 400 years old, is a nature lover's paradise. The sheer scale and beauty of the tree is awe-inspiring.

Here are some highlights of my visit:

- *Breathtaking Architecture*: The tree's intricate network of roots, branches, and aerial roots is a marvel.

- *Peaceful Ambiance*: The surroundings are peaceful and serene, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and meditation.

- *Photography Haven*: The unique architecture and beautiful surroundings make it a photographer's paradise.

- *Rich History*: The tree is steeped in history and mythology, adding to its charm.

- *Well-Maintained*: The surroundings are clean and well-maintained, making it a pleasure to visit.

- *Picnic Spot*: The tree's sprawling canopy provides a perfect spot for a picnic with family and friends.

- *Nature Education*: The tree is a great spot for nature enthusiasts and educators to teach about the importance of conservation and sustainability.

If you're in Bengaluru and love nature, Dodda Alada Mara is definitely worth a visit!

Highly recommended for nature enthusiasts, photography buffs, and anyone looking for a peaceful retreat!"

A really great airport! You really don't feel like you're in an Indian airport :D The passenger flow has been designed to facilitate smooth experience. The interiors are done up well. Kempegowda International Airport is hands down one of the best airports in India. The cleanliness, efficiency, and overall ambiance truly stand out. From the moment you enter, everything feels smooth ‚Äî from check-in counters to security checks, the staff is courteous and helpful.

This was my first visit to Bangalore International Airport and my experience was so awesome that I can't describe it in words.

Specifically I will write about Termal-2 as most of the photos I have taken at Terminal 2. This terminal looks like a place in our imagination. From the very first step to the last step you would only be surprised by the artwork and the theme which is prevalent every single corner of the terminal.

They have set a benchmark for this airport. Its clean, green and definitely enjoyable. If you have passion for photography you would not stop yourself from capturing the beauty inside.

Inside the terminal you would get everything of your choice. Everything is well thought out. Instructions are clear to follow. There is no clutter. The design language follows something natural. So you feel you are in a special place.

I would not write much but I want to say that if it's your first visit here then it would remain in your heart forever. Definitely I am proud of my country for achieving this kind of artwork in an airport terminal. It's the best.üíô

Hands down the best airport in India, and I genuinely think it cannot get better than this. As someone who travels to Bangalore every week, I love how easy and traveller-friendly this place is. Firstly, it is absolutely stunning. It is spacious, so much so that you might actually lose sight of where the airport ends. It has some of the best caf√©s and shopping stores inside, enough to keep you engaged even if you have extra time to spare.

What truly stands out is the cleanliness. Every corner of the airport is spotless, and the maintenance standards are consistently top-notch. Passing through security and other checks is also a breeze. The entire process is smooth, fast, and incredibly well-managed, with helpful staff available at every step to guide you. Whether it is check-in, security, immigration, or boarding, you feel supported throughout without ever feeling rushed or lost.

Overall, Bangalore Airport sets a benchmark for what a great travel experience should look like.

Kempegowda International Airport‚Äôs Terminal 2 (T2) in Bengaluru redefines travel with its ‚ÄúTerminal in a Garden‚Äù concept. Inspired by the city‚Äôs Garden City identity, T2 features lush green walls, vertical gardens, and serene indoor landscapes using sustainable materials like bamboo and rammed earth.
Smart systems, renewable energy, and efficient layouts ensure a smooth and sustainable passenger journey.

T2 isn‚Äôt just a travel hub‚Äîit‚Äôs a green, innovative, and culturally rich space that showcases Bengaluru‚Äôs modern spirit while staying rooted in nature and tradition. It's peaceful and immersive in nature!!

Kempegowda Airport is honestly one of the prettiest airports I‚Äôve been to! Just like the rest of Bengaluru, it‚Äôs full of greenery, flowers, and even some cool historical monument setups. The whole vibe is so peaceful and aesthetic.
When I went, the check-in process was smooth, and I couldn‚Äôt stop admiring how nice everything looked. If you‚Äôre in Bengaluru or passing through, you should definitely check it out. Totally worth a visit!
ü§åü§å

One of the best and cleanest airports in India. The setup at the exit is so great, you have so many food options, freshly brewed coffee and beer both. Great food, a washroom a huge Taj hotel and what not. You could also get bouquet from a flower shop at the airport.

I am talking mostly about T1 here, as T2 is slightly different and I guess getting ready. For transportation you have many options taxis, buses etc. You can also get power points at multiple locations. I will the best airport to have a layover currently.

In the early 18th century, Maharaja Jai Singh II of Jaipur constructed five Jantar Mantar in total, in New Delhi, Jaipur, Ujjain, Mathura and Varanasi; they were completed between 1724 and 1735. Of these, the observatory at Mathura and the fort that protected it were destroyed before 1857.[4]
As part of Jantar Mantar there were many instruments like Samrat Yantra, Jai Prakash Yantra, Disha Yantra, Rama Yantra, Chakra Yantra, Rashiwalya Yantra, Dingash Yantra and Utaansh Yantra. The primary purpose of the instruments was to compile astronomical tables and to predict the times and movements of the sun, moon and planets.

Rashtrapati Bhavan, located in New Delhi, is the official residence of the President of India. Spanning 320 acres, it includes the main building, Mughal Gardens, and staff quarters. Designed by British architect Sir Edwin Lutyens, it was completed in 1929 and originally served as the residence of the Viceroy of India.

The grand structure has 340 rooms, including the President‚Äôs office, reception halls, guest rooms, and a massive Durbar Hall. The architecture blends Indian and European styles, featuring domes, pillars, and intricate carvings. The Mughal Gardens, open to the public during specific months, showcase a stunning collection of flowers and fountains.

Rashtrapati Bhavan is a symbol of India‚Äôs democracy and heritage, hosting official events and ceremonies. It stands at the western end of Rajpath, facing India Gate. With its historical and architectural significance, it remains one of India‚Äôs most prestigious landmarks, attracting visitors from across the world.

Safdarjung Tomb is a stunning 18th-century Mughal-era mausoleum in Delhi, India. Built in 1754, it serves as the final resting place of Nawab Safdarjung, the prime minister of the Mughal Empire. The tomb showcases a blend of Mughal and Persian architectural styles, featuring a grand sandstone and marble structure, lush gardens, and intricate carvings.

Located near Lodhi Road, this historical site is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and photographers. The symmetrical gardens surrounding the tomb follow the classic Charbagh layout, similar to Humayun‚Äôs Tomb. Visitors can explore the well-preserved domes, arched gateways, and the impressive central dome.

Safdarjung Tomb is open to visitors daily, with an entry fee for both Indian and foreign tourists. It‚Äôs a peaceful retreat in the bustling city, perfect for those interested in Mughal history and architecture.

It was built in 1754 in the late Mughal Empire style for Nawab Safdarjung. The monument has an ambience of spaciousness and an imposing presence with its domed and arched red, brown and white coloured structures. Safdarjung, Nawab of Awadh, was made prime minister of the Mughal Empire (Wazir ul-Mamlak-i-Hindustan) when Ahmed Shah Bahadur ascended the throne in 1748.The tomb is located near the Safdarjung Airport at the T junction of Lodi Road and Aurobindo Marg (earlier name Mehrauli Road) in New Delhi.
Safdar Jang, born Mirza Muqim Abul Mansur Khan, was the second Nawab of Awadh and one of the most powerful nobles during the declining years of the Mughal Empire. Following the death of Emperor Muhammad Shah in 1748, he moved to Delhi. Under the newly crowned Mughal Emperor Ahmad Shah Bahadur, Safdar Jang was appointed as the Prime Minister (Wazir) with the title Vazir ul-Mamalk-i-Hindustan when the Mughal Empire's influence had dwindled to only parts of northern India.

As Wazir, Safdar Jang effectively wielded considerable power, reducing the emperor to a mere figurehead. His dominance and authoritarian approach, however, earned him strong opposition from rival nobles, including Imad-ul-Mulk and Najib-ud-Daulah, who led a faction against him. Contrary to popular belief, the Marathas were not directly involved in his ousting. After a series of battles, Safdar Jang was forced to leave Delhi in 1753 due to mounting opposition, returning to Awadh where he died in 1754.

Following his death his son Nawab Shuja-ud-Daula sought permission from the Mughal emperor to construct a tomb for his father in Delhi. The tomb, designed by an Abyssinian architect named Bilal Muhammad Khan, was built at a cost of approximately three lakh rupees and remains a significant example of late Mughal architecture.

To the south of this tomb is the historic site of the battle that was fought in 1386 between Timur of Mangol and Sultan Mahmud Khan of the Tughluq dynasty when the latter was defeated.

We visited Hauz Khas Complex in New Delhi in December 2024. It indeed serves as a wonderful reminder of Delhi‚Äôs rich history.

The complex traces its origins to the 13th century during the reign of Alauddin Khilji. The term ‚ÄòHauz Khas‚Äô translates to ‚ÄòRoyal Tank‚Äô in Persian, referring to the large water reservoir built to supply water to the city of Siri. Later, Firoz Shah Tughlaq restored the tank and added significant structures, including a madrasa (Islamic seminary), mosque, and his own tomb .

You can easily spend more than half a day exploring the different structures, and some areas make great spots for photos. The history is evident here in the madrasa and Firoz Shah‚Äôs tomb.

The serene Hauz Khas lake serves as a wonderful accompaniment to the complex. The complex is open everyday from 10:30am to 7pm.

Nearest metro station: Hauz Khas

Entry fees: 20 rupees for Indian Nationals and 250 rupees for foreign tourists

Hauz Khas Complex, located in South Delhi, India, is a historic site renowned for its architectural significance and vibrant surroundings.

History: The name "Hauz Khas" is derived from Persian, where 'Hauz' means "water tank" and 'Khas' denotes "royal," translating to "Royal Tank." This reservoir was originally constructed by Alauddin Khilji during his reign from 1296 to 1316 to supply water to the inhabitants of Siri, the second city of Delhi. Later, during Firuz Shah Tughlaq's rule (1351‚Äì1388), the tank was desilted, and several significant structures were added around it, including a madrasa (Islamic seminary), a mosque, and Firuz Shah's own tomb. These additions transformed the area into a prominent center for Islamic education and architecture. 

Monuments and Structures: The complex houses several notable structures:

Madrasa: An Islamic learning center established by Firuz Shah Tughlaq, showcasing Indo-Islamic architectural styles.

Mosque: A place of worship adjacent to the madrasa, reflecting the architectural aesthetics of the Tughlaq dynasty.

Firuz Shah's Tomb: The final resting place of Sultan Firuz Shah Tughlaq, centrally located within the complex.

Pavilions and Cenotaphs: Scattered throughout the gardens, these structures add to the historical ambiance of the site.

Chor Minar: Known as the "Tower of Thieves," historically believed to have displayed the heads of executed thieves as a deterrent during the Khilji dynasty. 

Visiting Hours: The Hauz Khas Complex is open daily from 10:30 AM to 7:00 PM. It is advisable to visit during early morning or late afternoon hours to avoid the midday heat and to experience the site in pleasant lighting conditions. 

Facilities: Adjacent to the complex is the Deer Park, a well-maintained green space home to spotted deer, peacocks, rabbits, and various bird species. The park offers walking trails, a rose garden, and a duck pond, providing a serene environment for relaxation. Additionally, the surrounding Hauz Khas Village has evolved into a hub for art galleries, boutiques, cafes, and restaurants, blending historical charm with contemporary culture. 

How to Reach from New Delhi Railway Station and Indira Gandhi International Airport:

From New Delhi Railway Station: Hauz Khas is approximately 12 kilometers away. You can take the Yellow Line of the Delhi Metro from New Delhi Station to Hauz Khas Metro Station. Alternatively, taxis and auto-rickshaws are readily available.

From Indira Gandhi International Airport: The complex is about 16 kilometers from the airport. Travelers can use app-based cab services or airport taxis for a direct journey. For a more economical option, take the Airport Express Line to New Delhi Metro Station, then transfer to the Yellow Line towards Hauz Khas. 

Best Season to Visit: The ideal time to explore Hauz Khas Complex is during the cooler months, from October to March. During this period, the weather is pleasant, making it comfortable to walk around and fully appreciate the historical and cultural offerings of the area. 

Hauz Khas Complex offers a unique blend of Delhi's rich historical heritage and its dynamic modern culture, making it a must-visit destination for both history enthusiasts and casual travelers.

The Purana Qila was built by the Mughal Emperor Humayun as a part of his new city of Dinpanah in the 16th century. One might wonder, as to what accords this particular fort the pride of place to be termed as ‚Äúthe Purana Qila‚Äù or ‚Äúthe Old Fort‚Äù, when there exist much older forts in Delhi. The answer to this question lies in an age known to us not so much through monuments and material culture, but through the kaleidoscopic world of myths and legends.

A strong local tradition believes that the area in which the Purana Qila stands today is the site of Indraprastha, the capital of the Pandavas of the great epic Mahabharata. It is for the same reason that the Purana Qila is often called the ‚ÄúPandavon ka Qila''.

Nice tourist place, there are demolished forts built by Ghiyashuddin Tuglak. From there you see the entire surrounding locations and also see deerü¶å. The evening visit of this fort is awesome because pictures of the sunset are nice. There are more crowds on weekend days. ‚Ä¶

History
Tughlaqabad Fort, in South Delhi, was founded in 1321 by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, the first Tughlaq dynasty ruler, to protect his empire from Mongol invasions. Built over four years, this massive stone fortress was abandoned by 1327 after Ghiyasuddin‚Äôs death, possibly due to water scarcity or a curse linked to saint Nizamuddin Auliya, whose tomb construction was disrupted by the fort‚Äôs demands. It briefly served as the dynasty‚Äôs third capital before being deserted.

What Can You See There
Spanning 6.5 km, the fort‚Äôs ruins include crumbling ramparts, bastions, and underground passages. Highlights are the palace remnants, a stepwell (baoli), and Ghiyasuddin‚Äôs tomb across the road, linked by a causeway. The elevated citadel offers panoramic Delhi views. Scattered stones and wild vegetation add a haunting charm, drawing history buffs and photographers.

Facilities Available
Facilities are minimal‚Äîbasic signage, a small parking area (free but limited), and no restrooms or food stalls inside. Visitors need water and sun protection, as shade is scarce. Accessibility is challenging due to uneven terrain and lack of ramps.

Timings
Open daily, 7:00 AM‚Äì5:00 PM, managed by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). Entry may close earlier in winter or during maintenance.

Best Season to Visit
October to March offers pleasant weather (15‚Äì25¬∞C), ideal for exploring the sprawling ruins. Summers (April‚ÄìJune) hit 45¬∞C, and monsoons (July‚ÄìSeptember) make paths slippery.

Ticket Prices
‚Çπ25 (Indians), ‚Çπ300 (foreigners); free for kids under 15. Camera fees: ‚Çπ25 (still), ‚Çπ200 (video). Tickets are cash-only at the gate.

Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a hidden gem in Delhi, offering a fascinating mix of history, nature, and tranquility. Unlike the more crowded tourist spots, this park feels like a peaceful escape, yet it holds centuries of heritage within its ruins.

The park is home to over 100 historical monuments, including the stunning Jamali Kamali Mosque, Rajon Ki Baoli (a stepwell), and the Tomb of Balban. Walking through the ruins, you can feel the remnants of Delhi‚Äôs past empires, from the Delhi Sultanate to the Mughals. The intricate architecture and carvings, especially in Jamali Kamali, are breathtaking, though some structures could use better maintenance.

What makes this place special is the serene atmosphere. Unlike the nearby Qutub Minar, which is always packed, Mehrauli Archaeological Park offers plenty of quiet corners to explore. It‚Äôs a great spot for photography, history lovers, and morning walkers. However, signage is limited, so it‚Äôs best to do some research before visiting.

The best time to visit is early morning or late afternoon, as the park lacks shaded areas, and Delhi‚Äôs heat can be intense. Entry is free, making it a budget-friendly experience.

Overall, if you love history and exploring lesser-known places, Mehrauli Archaeological Park is a must-visit. It‚Äôs a reminder of Delhi‚Äôs layered history, just waiting to be discovered.

Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, carry water, and visit with a group if exploring late in the evening.

A Haven of Peace and Harmony

Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia

If you find yourself in Delhi, a visit to the Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia is an absolute must. This sacred space pulsates with an atmosphere of profound peace, prosperity, love, and happiness that is truly captivating. From the moment you step into the bustling lanes leading to the shrine, you are enveloped in a unique cultural experience that touches your soul.

The air resonates with devotional music (Qawwali), the scent of incense, and the murmur of prayers. It's a place where people from all walks of life, irrespective of their religious beliefs, come together with unwavering faith. Witnessing this unity and devotion is incredibly moving. The architecture, steeped in history, adds to the spiritual ambiance, transporting you to another time.

While the overall experience is deeply enriching, it's wise to be mindful of your surroundings. Like any popular religious site, there can be individuals who may try to exploit the faith of visitors through donation scams. It's best to be cautious and avoid engaging with anyone who approaches you with unsolicited offers for Dargah updates or requests for your personal information. Stick to official donation boxes if you wish to contribute.

Despite this minor caution, the Dargah Hazrat Nizamuddin Aulia remains a powerful and uplifting experience. It's a place where you can find solace, witness the beauty of shared faith, and immerse yourself in a vibrant cultural tapestry. Don't miss the opportunity to experience this spiritual heart of Delhi.

Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya was a 13th-century Sufi saint of the Chishti Order, known for his deep spirituality, compassion, and service to humanity. Born in 1238 in Badayun, he lost his father early and moved to Delhi with his mother for education. He became a disciple of Baba Farid and later his spiritual successor.

His khanqah in Delhi became a symbol of love, peace, and equality, welcoming people of all faiths. He preached selflessness, unity, and devotion to God, staying away from politics despite the turbulent times. His teachings were carried forward by his beloved disciple Amir Khusrau.

He passed away in 1325, and his Dargah in Delhi remains a revered spiritual site. His life stands as a beacon of love, humility, and divine service.

Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is one of those few places which stays with you long after you leave. As soon as you step inside the gates, all the noise of Delhi seems to fade away and you get enveloped by a sense of calm. The golden dome of Bangla Sahib Gurudwara shines royally along with the hymns that are being sung. The kohinoor of Delhi pauses for one to take that deep breath and relax.

This place is special because of how everyone is treated equally. Everyone can enter the community kitchen and serve themselves food 24*7, there are no restrictions. Watching the hardworking volunteers tirelessly chop vegetables, cook, serve and clean is moving to say the least. Dip your feet in the sarovar and the rest of the world gets blindsided by the quiet charm of the Gurudwara.

In the night, this Gurudwara serves a different purpose. All the prayers from the bangla combined with the splashes from the sarovar can be heard clearly. The marble monument gets illuminated and the water reflects all the night lights. For hours, one can sit without overthinking and relax.

People come here for many different reasons, but everyone is bound to get at least a little bit tired. All of this Islam and serenity, along with you are bound to feel at least just a bit weary at one time, and Bangla will take care of you at that moment.

Rather, it contributes to the sensation that you are entering into something larger than yourself. Your reasons of faith, curiosity, or simply wanting to take a moment of silence will ensure you leave with its sense of calm.

Gurudwara Bangla Sahib is a prominent Sikh temple located in the heart of Delhi, near Connaught Place. This historic gurudwara is associated with the eighth Sikh Guru, Guru Har Krishan, who stayed here in 1664.¬π

*History and Significance*

The gurudwara was originally a bungalow owned by Raja Jai Singh of Jaipur, which was later converted into a gurudwara by Sikh General Sardar Baghel Singh in 1783.¬≤ The gurudwara is famous for its holy water tank, known as the "Sarovar," which is believed to have healing properties.

*Architecture and Features*

The gurudwara is built in a classic Sikh style, with a blend of Mughal and Rajput architectural influences.¬≥ The central golden dome is a striking feature, and the complex also includes a langar hall, a museum, and a library.

*Visiting Details*

- *Timings:* The gurudwara is open 24 hours, but the langar timings are from 9 am to 3 pm and 7 pm to 10 pm.
- *Entry Fee:* There is no entry fee.
- *Dress Code:* Visitors are expected to dress modestly and cover their heads.

Lakshmi Narayan Mandir or Birla Mandir in Delhi is a serene and beautifully crafted temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu and Goddess Lakshmi. Its intricate carvings, peaceful ambiance, and grand architecture make it a must-visit. The temple offers a spiritual retreat amidst the city's hustle. Evening aarti adds to its divine charm.Free lockers are available outside the temple.

Shri Laxmi Narayan Temple, popularly known as Birla Mandir, is a serene and architecturally splendid Hindu temple located in New Delhi. Dedicated to Lord Vishnu (Narayan) and Goddess Lakshmi, the temple was constructed between 1933 and 1939 by the Birla family and inaugurated by Mahatma Gandhi, who insisted it be open to people of all castes and faiths. The temple showcases the Nagara style of Hindu temple architecture, featuring red sandstone and white marble. Its main shikhara (tower) rises to about 160 feet, and the interiors are adorned with intricate carvings and fresco paintings. Materials like Kota stone from Makarana, Agra, Jaisalmer, and Kota were used in its construction.

Peaceful place in the heart of city. Religious functions are held regularly. The place is clean and maintained well. There is a small food and snacks stall also. You have to deposit your mobile before entering into the temple though you can use it outside the temple in the temple complex area.

A Day at Majnu Ka Tila ‚Äì Felt Like I Left Delhi Without Leaving

If you ever want to take a quick break from the busy life of Delhi, Majnu Ka Tila is the perfect place. The moment I reached there, I felt like I had entered a whole new world ‚Äî almost like I‚Äôd been teleported to another country.

The streets are full of color, with Tibetan flags hanging above, the smell of incense in the air, and soft chants coming from the Buddhist Monastery. It was so peaceful. I spent some quiet time inside the monastery, just looking around and feeling calm. The walls were beautifully painted, and the monks were sitting peacefully ‚Äî it really made me slow down and enjoy the moment.

After that, I decided to try some local food. I had Laphing ‚Äî it‚Äôs a cold, spicy Tibetan snack. Honestly, I didn‚Äôt like it much. Maybe because I‚Äôm not used to the texture and taste. But I‚Äôm glad I tried it! Then I had a boba tea for ‚Çπ150 ‚Äî now that was nice and refreshing.

Walking around, I noticed how different everything felt. The shops, the food, the people ‚Äî it didn‚Äôt feel like Delhi at all. It was calm, colorful, and full of culture.

How to Reach Majnu Ka Tila

By Metro:
Take the Yellow Line and get off at Vidhan Sabha Station. From there, you can walk (about 20 minutes) or take an auto for ‚Çπ30‚Äì‚Çπ50.

By Bus:
You can also take a DTC bus that stops near Majnu Ka Tila.

By Car:
It‚Äôs not the best idea to take your own car because parking can be a problem.

Timings

The market is open every day from 11 AM to 9 PM.

The monastery is best to visit between 9 AM and 6 PM.

Food I Tried

Laphing ‚Äì ‚Çπ60: Spicy and cold snack. Not my favorite, but worth trying once.

Boba Tea ‚Äì ‚Çπ150: Sweet and fun to drink, especially if you like chewy tapioca balls.

Final Thoughts

Majnu Ka Tila gave me a peaceful break from regular city life. The place is full of culture, calm vibes, and tasty food. Even if you don‚Äôt like everything you try (like I didn‚Äôt love Laphing), it‚Äôs still a really cool experience. I‚Äôll definitely go again ‚Äî maybe try something new next time!

The National Science Museum in Delhi, a haven for science enthusiasts, offers a fascinating journey through the realms of science and technology. The museum houses a vast collection of exhibits, ranging from interactive displays to historical artifacts, that cater to visitors of all ages.
One of the highlights of the museum is its interactive exhibits, which allow visitors to experiment with various scientific concepts. These hands-on experiences make learning engaging and enjoyable, particularly for children. The museum also boasts impressive displays on topics such as energy, space exploration, and the human body.
However, while the museum offers a wealth of knowledge and entertainment, there's room for improvement. Some of the exhibits could benefit from modernization to keep pace with the latest advancements in science and technology. Additionally, the maintenance of certain areas, such as the washrooms, could be enhanced to provide a more comfortable visitor experience.
Despite these minor shortcomings, the National Science Museum remains a valuable resource for education and inspiration. It is a place where visitors can ignite their curiosity, expand their knowledge, and appreciate the wonders of science. With a few upgrades and improvements, the museum can continue to be a leading science center in India and a must-visit destination for both locals and tourists.

Overall worth visiting üôÇ

The Shankar's International Dolls Museum, located in Delhi, is a renowned cultural institution showcasing an impressive collection of over 6,500 dolls from around 85 countries. Established in 1965 by K. Shankar Pillai, a famous political cartoonist, the museum is split into two sections: one dedicated to dolls from India and the other to dolls from other parts of the world.

Key Highlights:

1. Indian Section: Displays a wide variety of traditional dolls representing the diverse cultures and attire of different states.

2. International Section: Features dolls gifted by countries worldwide, including Japan, the United States, and Germany, among others.

3. Special Attractions: The museum houses rare pieces, such as ceremonial dolls and replicas of historical or cultural figures.

The museum is located at Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg and is accessible from the ITO metro station. It is an excellent destination for children and adults alike, offering a glimpse into global and Indian heritage through meticulously crafted dolls.

Visitor Information:

Timings: Open Tuesday to Sunday, from 10 AM to 5:30 PM; closed on Mondays.

Entry Fee: Nominal charges for adults and children.

For more information, you can visit their official website or check local tourism resources.

The National Museum in New Delhi, located on Janpath Road, stands as one of India's most prominent cultural institutions, offering a comprehensive journey through over 5,000 years of the nation's rich history and heritage. Established in 1949, the museum houses an extensive collection of more than 200,000 artifacts, encompassing a diverse range of periods and styles.
Visitors can explore a multitude of galleries that showcase India's artistic and historical evolution. Highlights include relics from the Indus Valley Civilization, such as seals and pottery; intricate bronze sculptures from the Chola dynasty; and a significant collection of Buddhist art, including sacred relics of the Buddha, which attract pilgrims and art enthusiasts alike. The museum also features exquisite Mughal miniature paintings, ancient coins, textiles, and tribal artifacts, providing a holistic view of India's diverse cultural tapestry.
The museum's layout is thoughtfully organized, allowing visitors to navigate through various epochs seamlessly. Interactive exhibits and informative displays enhance the educational experience, making it accessible to both casual visitors and scholars. Additionally, the museum offers virtual tours and online exhibitions, enabling a broader audience to engage with its collections remotely.
Open from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM (Tuesday to Friday) and until 8:00 PM on weekends, the museum provides ample time for exploration. Entry fees are modest, with Indian nationals charged ‚Çπ20 and foreign visitors ‚Çπ650. Students up to class 12 can enter free of charge upon presenting valid identification.
Situated near significant landmarks like India Gate and Rashtrapati Bhavan, the National Museum is easily accessible via the Udyog Bhawan metro station. Its central location makes it a convenient stop for tourists and locals interested in delving into India's profound historical and cultural legacy.

The National Rail Museum in Delhi is a captivating journey through India's rich railway heritage. Spread across a sprawling 10 acres, the museum houses an impressive collection of over 100 real-size exhibits, both indoors and outdoors. From vintage steam locomotives like the iconic Fairy Queen, the world's oldest working steam engine, to opulent saloon cars once used by Indian royalty, each exhibit tells a unique story of India's railway evolution.
The outdoor exhibits allow you to walk alongside these magnificent machines, imagining the bygone era of steam and speed. Informative plaques accompany each exhibit, detailing their history and significance. Inside, the museum offers a treasure trove of railway artifacts, including signaling equipment, antique furniture, and historical photographs, providing a deeper understanding of the intricate workings and cultural impact of the railways.
A highlight for visitors of all ages is the toy train ride that chugs around the museum grounds, offering a delightful overview of the exhibits. For a more immersive experience, don't miss the state-of-the-art simulators that provide a virtual feel of driving a train. The museum also features an indoor gallery showcasing the future of railways, making it a comprehensive experience for both history enthusiasts and those curious about modern advancements. With its well-maintained exhibits and engaging atmosphere, the National Rail Museum is a must-visit destination in Delhi, offering a fascinating glimpse into the lifeline of a nation.

This is THE definitive museum of Delhi.  With an incredibly warm staff and helpful signs and more different types of bathrooms and toilets than I ever thought possible in one place this is a must see in Delhi.

The museum strikes an incredible balance between taking this important subject, seriously, and promoting public health, including the pivotal role in India and public health research has had and making us all healthier while maintaining a great humorous and accessible side to human bodily functions.  Our kids enjoyed learning about the deep ancient roots of the modern toilet system and funny humorous takes and comics that they had posted in the museum about bathroom situations.  They have relics and specimens of toilets from almost every age in history.

This is easy access to the airport, and a great option if you have only a few hours for a layover and don‚Äôt want to fight through the murderous traffic to red fort.

A truly wonderful place to visit. It's extremely clean, well laid out, and surrounded by greenery. The staff are friendly, knowledgeable, and welcoming. You get the feeling that they're truly passionate about their foundation and answering all your queries. The museum is also fully air conditioned and spotless, a welcome escape from the Delhi heat.

The museum is actually just part of the experience. Their main goal is to raise awareness about the importance of accessible toilet facilities and clean drinking water. They have another building focusing on their water sanitation and effluent treatment initiatives. Outside, you'll see the different types of septic systems they construct in rural areas. adding to that, the museum is completely free to the public.

When I visited, it was completely empty. They're open 7 days a week. There's also plenty of parking available inside if you're arriving by car. This museum is definitely worth a visit if you're visiting Delhi with family and friends.

Visiting the Indira Gandhi Memorial Museum in Delhi is like stepping into a time capsule of India's political history. The museum, once the residence of India's first female Prime Minister, offers a deep insight into Indira Gandhi‚Äôs personal and political journey.

One of the most fascinating aspects of the museum is how it preserves her family life and childhood memories. From photographs of her early years to glimpses of her living quarters and study room, every corner narrates a story. The study room, filled with books and personal belongings, showcases her intellectual depth and love for literature. Her collection of books on history, politics, and global affairs reflects her visionary leadership.

The museum also highlights her contributions to India, from the Green Revolution to her role in shaping modern India‚Äôs foreign policies. Rare photographs and letters give a personal touch to her journey, making visitors appreciate her dedication to the nation.

The most emotional part of the museum is the preserved path where she took her last steps before her tragic assassination. The glass-encased bloodstains serve as a stark reminder of her sacrifice for the country.

Overall, the Indira Gandhi Memorial Museum is a must-visit for history lovers and those who wish to understand the life of one of India‚Äôs most powerful leaders. It‚Äôs not just a museum; it‚Äôs an experience that leaves you inspired.
‚≠ê Highly recommended for history buffs, students, and anyone interested in India‚Äôs political legacy!

So while the experience is definitely fun and memorable, the duration feels a bit short, especially considering the ticket price. It‚Äôs slightly on the expensive side for the time you spend inside, but if you‚Äôre visiting as a group or family, it feels more justified because everyone can participate and enjoy.

A special mention to the staff ‚Äî they were extremely supportive and polite throughout. They patiently explained how each illusion works and also helped us take good photos at certain exhibits, ensuring we didn‚Äôt miss out on the best angles.

In summary, the Museum of Illusions is a unique, one-time visit spot in Delhi. It may feel a little costly for a short visit, but it offers a fresh, engaging experience that‚Äôs especially enjoyable for kids and those who love interactive activities. Definitely recommended for a fun outing, though it might not be something you‚Äôd return to repeatedly.
