The National Zoological Park, commonly known as Delhi Zoo, is a 176-acre facility located near the historic Purana Qila in New Delhi, India. Established on November 1, 1959, the zoo is home to approximately 1,350 animals representing around 130 species from across the globe. 

Key Attractions:

Diverse Wildlife: The zoo houses a variety of animals, including the Royal Bengal Tiger, Indian Rhinoceros, Asiatic Lion, and numerous bird species. 

Conservation Efforts: It participates in breeding programs for endangered species such as the Bengal Tiger, Indian Rhinoceros, and Asiatic Lion. 

Visitor Information:

Timings: The zoo operates from 8:30 AM to 5:30 PM, with the last entry at 4:30 PM. It remains closed on Fridays. 

Tickets: Tickets are available exclusively online and can be booked up to 14 days in advance. 

Facilities: Visitors can rent battery-operated vehicles for a guided tour of the zoo. Basic amenities like restrooms are available; however, there are no cafes or canteens inside, and outside food is not permitted. Carrying water is advisable. 

Best Time to Visit: The winter months, from October to March, offer pleasant weather, making it an ideal time to explore the zoo. 

Additional Tips:

Attire: Wear comfortable shoes and clothing suitable for walking. If visiting with young children, consider bringing a stroller. 

Safety: Always maintain a safe distance from the enclosures and follow the zoo's guidelines to ensure a secure and enjoyable experience.

A visit to the National Zoological Park offers an educational and engaging experience, highlighting India's rich biodiversity and ongoing conservation efforts.

Lodhi Garden is a beautiful and spacious green oasis in the heart of Delhi. It‚Äôs perfect for a morning walk, jogging, yoga, or just relaxing in nature. The well-maintained gardens make it feel like a botanical paradise, with a wide variety of plants and trees. It's also a great spot for bird watching and photography‚Äîthere's always something interesting to capture.

The historical monuments scattered throughout the park add a unique charm and cultural depth, making it more than just a park. It's ideal for a peaceful family picnic or a solo stroll to unwind. Highly recommended for nature lovers, fitness enthusiasts, and anyone looking to escape the city's hustle for a while.
Playground
For families with children, Lodhi Garden features a dedicated children's play area equipped with slides and swings, providing a safe and enjoyable space for kids to play. Additionally, the park boasts a duck pond, butterfly garden, and open gym facilities, catering to visitors of all ages.
Toilets
The park also provides free public restrooms, such as the SBM Toilet near Gate No. 7, which is functional and maintained by M/S Lion Manpower Solution Pvt Ltd. While these facilities are generally usable, it's a good idea to carry your own tissue paper or sanitizing wipes, as amenities might differ from what you're accustomed to.
Dog-friendliness
For dog owners, Lodhi Garden is welcoming. Leashed dogs are allowed between 8 AM and 5 PM, offering ample space for your furry friends to explore. However, off-leash dogs are not permitted, and it's advisable to be cautious of stray dogs in the area.
Picnic area
The lush green lawns are ideal for picnics ‚Äî you‚Äôll often find families and groups of friends relaxing and enjoying their time here, especially on weekends. The park is a perfect mix of history and greenery. It's clean, well-maintained, and feels safe even during early mornings or late evenings. A must-visit if you're looking for a refreshing break from the city‚Äôs chaos. It is a great spot if you're thinking about going to picnic with your family or friends. I really recommend this garden

Lodhi Garden is a beautiful and peaceful place to spend time with family and friends. The gardens are very well maintained, and there‚Äôs plenty of space for picnics, walks, or simply relaxing under the trees. I especially enjoyed seeing the historical monuments scattered throughout the park, they give you a wonderful glimpse into Delhi‚Äôs rich history.

It‚Äôs a great spot if you love nature, photography, or just want a quiet break from the busy city. I highly recommend visiting early in the morning or during sunset for the best experience. Overall, Lodhi Garden feels like a perfect mix of nature, culture, and history. Definitely worth a visit!

Lodhi Garden: A Perfect Blend of Nature, History & Serenity in the Heart of Delhi

Nestled in the heart of South Delhi, Lodhi Garden is one of the most cherished green spaces in the capital city. Sprawled across nearly 90 acres, it is more than just a park‚Äîit's a tranquil escape that beautifully combines nature, history, and architecture.

Ambience & Atmosphere:

Lodhi Garden is a peaceful haven, especially in the early morning and late evening hours. It‚Äôs frequented by morning walkers, yoga enthusiasts, fitness buffs, couples, and families alike. The air feels noticeably fresher, and the lush greenery, chirping birds, and open skies provide a refreshing contrast to Delhi‚Äôs otherwise hectic urban environment.

Historical Significance:

The garden is home to several 15th and 16th-century monuments from the Lodhi and Sayyid dynasties, including Sikandar Lodi‚Äôs Tomb, Shish Gumbad, Bara Gumbad, and Mohammed Shah‚Äôs Tomb. These structures are scattered across the landscape, giving the garden a heritage-rich character and making it a photographer‚Äôs paradise.

Activities & Attractions:

Walking and Jogging Tracks: Well-paved pathways meander through the garden, ideal for a morning jog or evening stroll.

Botanical Beauty: A wide variety of trees, flowering plants, and neatly maintained lawns offer a visual treat and make it a popular picnic spot.

Bird Watching: The park attracts a number of bird species‚Äîboth local and migratory‚Äîmaking it a nice spot for bird lovers.

Photography: Whether you're into nature photography or architectural shots, Lodhi Garden offers plenty of content.

Accessibility & Facilities:

Entry is free for all.
Located near Jor Bagh and Khan Market Metro stations, it‚Äôs easily accessible.

Clean public washrooms and ample seating areas are available.

There is a Bonsai Park and a small lake with a stone bridge that adds to the charm.

Best Time to Visit:

Early mornings are ideal, especially if you want to avoid the crowd and enjoy the soft sunlight filtering through the trees. Winters are particularly pleasant with blooming flowers and cool weather.

Sanjay Van is indeed a nearby attraction to the Qutub Minar, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Delhi, India. Sanjay Van is a sprawling city forest, spread over 10 square kilometers, offering a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.

To get to Sanjay Van from Qutub Minar, you can take a short drive or ride of about 20-30 minutes, depending on traffic. There are also public transportation options available, such as buses and auto-rickshaws.

Sanjay Van is a popular spot for nature lovers, joggers, and picnickers. The forest has several walking trails, a lake, and plenty of greenery, making it an ideal spot to relax and unwind.

If you're planning to visit Qutub Minar, I recommend combining it with a visit to Sanjay Van for a refreshing and rejuvenating experience!

Indraprastha Park in Delhi is a wonderful spot for a day out with friends or family. Known for its vast green expanse, this park offers something for everyone, making it a favorite destination for locals and tourists alike.

The park is spacious and thoughtfully designed, featuring an amphitheater, clean and accessible toilets, and a food court where visitors can enjoy a variety of snacks. For families with children, there‚Äôs an engaging kids‚Äô area equipped with swings, monkey bars, slides, and even a basketball court. For sports lovers, the nets for cricket and a dedicated jogging path are perfect for active visitors. This makes the park ideal not only for leisurely picnics but also for fitness enthusiasts who come here for their morning runs.

One of the unique highlights of the park is the large monument resembling a Stupa, which adds a touch of cultural significance and provides a picturesque backdrop for photos. The entire park is carpeted with lush grass, creating a relaxing atmosphere for visitors to unwind.

One of the best parts of visiting Indraprastha Park is that it‚Äôs completely free to enter, making it accessible to everyone. Parking, however, can be a bit tight, especially on weekends or during school trips, as many schools often bring students here for picnics.

Thanks to its prominent location, the park is easy to spot from the highway, and finding it is not an issue. Public transportation options are plentiful, with auto rickshaws, buses, and ride-hailing services like Ola and Uber readily available. Additionally, the park is only a short distance from the Indraprastha Metro Station, making it convenient for metro commuters as well.

Overall, Indraprastha Park is a fantastic place for a fun-filled outing, offering a mix of nature, recreation, and convenience. Whether you're planning a day with friends, a family picnic, or a solo run, this park won‚Äôt disappoint!

Review: Chennai International Airport ‚Äì Smooth & Well-Equipped

Chennai International Airport offers a comfortable experience, especially for international departures.

What‚Äôs Good:

‚úÖ Well-Maintained Facilities ‚Äì Clean, dust-free shops and good food options make the wait pleasant.
‚úÖ Smooth Departure Process ‚Äì Exiting the airport is hassle-free, particularly on the domestic side.
‚úÖ Last-Minute Shopping ‚Äì There are a few shops near the exit for quick purchases.

Final Verdict:

Overall, a well-managed airport with good amenities. Whether you‚Äôre departing internationally or domestically, the experience is smooth and efficient.

Chennai International Airport proved to be a decent transit point for my onward journey. While it wasn't a destination in itself, it had some notable aspects.
The availability of restaurants üçΩÔ∏è was quite satisfactory. There were enough options to grab a quick bite or a more substantial meal during the layover, catering to different tastes.
The washrooms üöΩ were generally clean and well-maintained, which is always a relief during travel.
One of the most striking features was the nice antique sculptures üóø at the arrival area. These beautifully showcased the rich cultural heritage and artistry of South India, providing a lovely glimpse into the region's beauty for transiting passengers like myself. It was a thoughtful touch! ‚ú®
However, there was a downside: the charging points üîå I tried weren't working. This was a bit inconvenient for travelers needing to power up their devices before the next flight. Hopefully, this is something that can be addressed. üõ†Ô∏è

Chennai International Airport (MAA) is the 5th busiest airport in India in terms of passengers handled in FY 2023-24 with footfall reaching 21.2 Million. Situated in Tirusulam near Chennai serving the metropolitan region, it has 3 terminals, out of which Terminal 1 and Terminal 4 caters to the domestic passengers while the most recent addition i.e Terminal 2 caters to the international traffic. Chennai Airport, has an edge which is its location. It is one of the few airports in India which has direct metro connectivity with the city. However, the cleanliness can be further improved. Similarly wifi was not connecting to the device hassle free unlike other airports. But the interiors of the airport showcase the beautiful tamil culture.

The airport is very nice and clean, and has some under construction places. Otherwise it's really easy to go to security check-in and terminal gates, only T4 is a bit far away from other terminals.

Ease access to drop points and pick-up points almost at the same place and for luggage belts too easy for access.

The metro is also at the nearest terminals.

I recently traveled through Chennai International Airport and noticed that there was no designated prayer room available. As someone who values the ability to fulfill my religious obligations during travel, it was disappointing to see fellow passengers having to pray in corners or isolated spaces.

Airports around the world, including many in India, are increasingly accommodating passengers of all faiths with quiet prayer or meditation rooms. I sincerely request the airport authorities to consider setting up a clean, quiet, and accessible prayer room for travelers. It would be a thoughtful and inclusive addition to the facilities here.

Thank you for your consideration.

Chennai International Airport, one of India's major gateways, offers an impressive travel experience. The airport excels in providing seamless support to passengers, with courteous staff and efficient services. Immigration processes are smooth and well-managed, ensuring minimal waiting times even during peak hours. The facilities are clean and well-maintained, contributing to a pleasant atmosphere.

Food options at the airport are exceptional, catering to both domestic and international travelers. A variety of restaurants, cafes, and kiosks serve an array of cuisines, from South Indian delicacies to global favorites. The quality of food is commendable, and there are options to suit all budgets, making it easy for travelers to enjoy a good meal before or after a flight.

Support services, including baggage handling and assistance for passengers with special needs, are top-notch. The airport staff is approachable and quick to assist, enhancing the overall travel experience. Additionally, clear signage and helpful information desks make navigation hassle-free.

Chennai International Airport stands out for its excellent infrastructure, passenger-focused services, and culinary offerings. It provides a welcoming and efficient environment, ensuring travelers leave with a positive impression of the city.

Chennai Airport has significantly improved its infrastructure with modernized terminals and better passenger amenities. The check-in and security process are smoother than before, though baggage claim can still be slow at times. Overall, it's a well-maintained airport, but there‚Äôs room for further enhancements in signage and seating areas.

Visiting the Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram was truly a memorable experience. Located right on the coast of the Bay of Bengal, this UNESCO World Heritage site is one of the oldest structural stone temples in South India, dating back to the 8th century during the reign of the Pallava dynasty.

The temple's location is breathtaking‚Äîset against the backdrop of the endless sea, with waves crashing gently nearby. The entire area has a peaceful aura, especially during sunrise or sunset when the golden light hits the ancient stones. The architecture is impressive, with intricate carvings and a layout that reflects the brilliance of early Dravidian temple design. The main shrine is dedicated to Lord Shiva, and there's also a smaller shrine for Lord Vishnu.

Getting there was fairly easy. I drove from Chennai, which is around 60 km away, and the journey along the East Coast Road (ECR) was smooth and scenic. Public transport is also available‚Äîbuses and taxis can be hired from Chennai or nearby towns like Chengalpattu. There‚Äôs ample parking near the temple complex and local guides available if you're interested in the detailed history.

The site is well-maintained, with clean paths, manicured gardens, and signboards explaining the temple‚Äôs background. I recommend spending at least an hour or two to really soak in the vibe. Don‚Äôt forget to carry water and wear comfortable footwear‚Äîit's best explored on foot.

Overall, the Shore Temple is not just a historical monument; it‚Äôs a peaceful retreat that connects you with India‚Äôs glorious past and nature's beauty all at once. A must-visit if you're anywhere near Tamil Nadu!

The Shore Temple of Mahabalipuram is one of the oldest stone temples in South India, dating back to the 8th century CE. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

It was constructed during the reign of Pallava King Narasimhavarman II (Rajasimha) (c. 700‚Äì728 CE).

It is part of the Mamallapuram group of monuments, which includes rock-cut caves and monolithic rathas (chariots).

Unlike earlier Pallava temples that were carved from rocks, the Shore Temple is one of the first structural temples built with granite blocks.

The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu, symbolizing the fusion of Shaivism and Vaishnavism.

The larger shrine faces east so that the first rays of the sun illuminate Lord Shiva‚Äôs sanctum.

A smaller shrine dedicated to Lord Vishnu in reclining form (Anantashayana) is also present.

A wall of Nandi sculptures surrounds the temple, protecting it from the sea.

European travelers in the 16th century mentioned "Seven Pagodas", claiming that six other temples once stood along the shore.

The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami exposed underwater structures near the temple, suggesting that remnants of ancient temples may still exist beneath the sea.

Over centuries, the temple suffered erosion from sea winds and saltwater.

The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has taken measures to protect it, including building protective groynes along the coast.

It remains an important site for both history and Hindu worship.

Thiruporur Murugan Temple, also known as Sri Kandaswamy Temple, is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Murugan. The temple has a deep-rooted history and is believed to be more than 1,300 years old.

The temple is said to have been originally built during the Pallava dynasty (7th‚Äì9th century CE).

The name "Thiruporur" translates to "the holy place of battle", referring to the battle between Lord Murugan and the demon Surapadman.

It is believed that Saint Agastya and Sage Chidambara Swamigal played a role in consecrating the temple.

The temple features a five-tiered Rajagopuram (entrance tower) and beautifully carved pillars.

Several inscriptions in Tamil and Grantha scripts from the Pallava and Vijayanagara periods describe land grants, temple donations, and religious rituals.

It is one of the 33 major Murugan temples in Tamil Nadu.

Devotees believe that worshipping Murugan here removes obstacles and grants success in life.

The temple courtyard houses several Sannidhis including that of Varasiddhi Vinayaka, Chokkanathar, Meenakshi Amman, Kali, Bhairava, Shanmuga with Valli and Deivanai. In the inner Praharam one can see the niches of Dakshinamurthy, Chandikeshwar, and Mahalakshmi. There is a separate shrine for Angaaran (Mars)

The belief is very strong here that people who cannot undertake the pilgrimage to the Palani temple can visit the Vadapalani temple with their offerings.

Arulmigu Sri Muthu Kumara Swamy Devasthanam is a prominent Hindu shrine dedicated to Lord Murugan, situated in the George Town area of Chennai.

The temple's origins trace back to the 17th century, with its establishment attributed to two devout individuals, Maari Chettiar and Kandappa Achari. During one of their pilgrimages to the Thiruporur Kandaswamy Temple, they discovered an idol of Lord Murugan beneath a peepal tree near a tank, believed to be revealed to them in a divine vision. This idol was subsequently installed in the current location, which was part of Muthiyalu Naicken's garden. The temple was constructed with significant contributions from Maari Chettiar, who is said to have sold his wife's jewelry to fund the construction.

The original structure, built in the 1670s, underwent reconstruction in the early 1800s using stone, enhancing its architectural grandeur. The temple complex spans approximately eight acres and features the 'Saravana Poigai' temple tank and the 'Magizham' tree as its sacred elements.

Kandhakottam Temple holds historical significance due to its association with Saint Ramalinga Swamigal, also known as Vallalar. As a child residing near the temple, he frequently visited and composed the devotional hymn 'Deiva Mani Malai' in praise of Lord Murugan at the age of nine. The temple also honors other saints, including Pamban Swamigal and Thiruporur Chidambara Swamigal, with dedicated shrines within its premises.

Triplicane Big Mosque (also called Wallajah Mosque) is a mosque located in Triplicane High Road, Triplicane in Chennai. Constructed in the Mughal architectural style, the mosque was built in 1795 by the family of Muhammad Ali Khan Wallajah, the Nawab of Arcot during 1765. It has a large prayer hall, a tank and a large ground in front. The entire structure is constructed with granite without the use of iron or wood.

The Nawab of Arcot was a loyal ally of the British who offered him Chepauk Palace where he could house his military and administrative buildings. It is believed that Nawab Muhammad Ali moved to Chepauk, located in Triplicane in 1768. There were around 20,000 Marakayar Muslims who moved with him to the city. It was then the largest community of Muslims in South India after Hyderabad. The Nawab had full control of the region and all the cases were resolved under Muslim Law irrespective of the religion of the accused. Historians believe that after the mosque was built, it added to the cultural mix in Triplicane, which had a famous Hindu temple in Parthasarathy Temple and the Portuguese Christian stronghold of San Thome.

The Nawab of Arcot was friendly towards fellow Hindus, appointing a Hindu as his chief personal secretary. A chronogram written in Persian by Raja Makhhan Lal Bahdur Khirat, the Hindu Munshi of the Nawab, is found on the entrance to the prayer hall. The mosque is the largest and one of the oldest in Chennai and is active as a place of worship. It is administered by Prince of Arcot Endowments Trust. Most of the administrative staff of the mosque are Hindus, symbolizing peaceful coexistence between the two religions.

place_name: Arulmigu Sri Parthasarathy Perumal Temple Tiruvallikeni
review_text:
I recently visited this ancient temple on a Saturday afternoon. The temple holds historical and spiritual significance, with its old yet well-maintained structure reflecting a deep sense of tradition.

Parking & Accessibility

Anticipating a potential parking issue, I arrived at 3:45 PM, about 15 minutes before the temple's opening time of 4:00 PM. This gave me ample time to find a suitable parking space. Fortunately, the temple provides plenty of paid parking, making it convenient for visitors. Additionally, it is well-equipped to accommodate differently-abled individuals, ensuring easy access to the premises.

Temple Experience

The temple doors officially opened at 4:10 PM. Since it was not a particularly auspicious day, the crowd was moderate, allowing for a peaceful visit without long wait times. The entire temple can be covered in about 30 to 45 minutes, making it an ideal visit for those with a tight schedule.

Prasadam

Before leaving, I had the opportunity to purchase prasadam. The offerings were fresh, delicious, and available at a reasonable price, adding a sweet touch to the spiritual experience.

Overall, my visit was smooth and fulfilling. With proper planning, parking is hassle-free, and the serene atmosphere allows for a meaningful darshan. I would recommend visiting on non-peak days for a relaxed experience.

place_name: Arulmigu Sri Parthasarathy Perumal Temple Tiruvallikeni
review_text:
The temple is unique in that it is one of the few shrines in the country dedicated to Krishna as Parthasarathy. The deity is depicted with a prominent mustache, which symbolizes his valor during the battle and his lineage as part of the Yadava dynasty. Additionally, the temple houses idols of three avatars of Vishnu: Narasimha, Rama, and Krishna, along with his consort Rukmini, brother Balarama, son Pradyumna, grandson Aniruddha, and Satyaki.

The Parthasarathy Temple is classified as one of the 108 Divya Desams, which are sacred temples glorified in the Alvar saints‚Äô literature from the 6th to 9th centuries CE. It is also known for its intricate carvings, towering gopurams (gateway towers), and vibrant murals depicting various mythological tales.

Visitors can experience the temple‚Äôs serene ambiance and captivating rituals, making it a spiritual haven for devotees and tourists alike. The temple follows the traditions of the Thenkalai sect of Vaishnavite tradition and subscribes to the Vaikhanasa Agama.

Nestled in the heart of Mylapore, Chennai, the Kapaleeshwarar Temple is a vibrant and sacred space dedicated to Lord Shiva. It stands as a beautiful representation of Dravidian architecture and South Indian temple culture. The towering gopuram (gateway tower) is adorned with colorful sculptures that instantly capture your attention.

One of the most heartwarming aspects of this temple is how rituals are conducted with deep devotion. The priests perform poojas in a traditional manner, and you‚Äôll notice that artificial lighting is kept to a minimum. Instead, the temple glows with the warmth of oil-lit diyas, creating a serene and spiritual ambiance.

Unlike many crowded temples, Kapaleeshwarar Temple offers a calm and respectful environment. There‚Äôs no pushing or shoving ‚Äî everyone is given time to offer their prayers and soak in the energy of the place. (Non-hindus are not allowed inside the temple)

Nayanars and Kapaleeshwarar Temple

The Nayanars were 63 poet-saints who lived between the 6th and 9th centuries CE and dedicated their lives to the worship of Lord Shiva. Their hymns, devotion, and stories form the spiritual foundation of Shaivism in Tamil Nadu.

What Makes It Special

Architecture: Classic South Indian temple structure with colorful stucco figures, pillars, and a sacred pond nearby.

Culture: The temple reflects the deep-rooted traditions of Tamil Nadu ‚Äî from the rituals to the attire of devotees.

Atmosphere: Peaceful, respectful, and welcoming to both devotees and tourists.

Temple Timings

Morning: 5:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 PM

Evening: 4:00 PM ‚Äì 9:30 PM
Best to visit early morning or around sunset to catch the aarti and avoid the heat.

Getting There

By Metro: Idk much about this.

By Bus/Auto: Easily accessible by city buses or autos from most parts of Chennai.

By Car: Parking might be tricky near the temple due to narrow roads, but paid parking lots are available nearby.

Shops & Food

Around the temple, you‚Äôll find small flower vendors, puja item sellers, and traditional snack shops. Put on gajra on hair.Don't miss out on trying some hot filter coffee or South Indian tiffin items from local eateries ‚Äî they add charm to the entire experience.

Whether you're a history buff, a spiritual seeker, or simply looking for a respite from the hustle and bustle of city life, Kapaleeswarar Temple is a must-visit destination.

The Annai Velankanni Church in Besant Nagar, Chennai, is a well-known Roman Catholic church and a place of pilgrimage dedicated to Our Lady of Good Health, popularly called Annai Velankanni. Here's some key information:

Location: Situated in Besant Nagar, close to Elliots Beach (Bessie), it‚Äôs a serene and iconic landmark in the area.

History: The church was inspired by the Basilica of Our Lady of Good Health in Velankanni, Tamil Nadu. It serves as a spiritual destination for locals and visitors alike.

Architecture: The church is known for its beautiful design, serene ambiance, and peaceful surroundings.

Special Events: The annual festival in September is a major attraction, drawing devotees from various parts of Chennai and beyond.

Accessibility: Easily reachable via public and private transport, with ample facilities for visitors..

Marina Beach, or simply the Marina, is a natural urban beach in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India, along the Bay of Bengal. The beach runs from near Fort St. George in the north to Foreshore Estate in the south, a distance of 6.0 km (3.7 mi), making it the second longest urban beach in the world, after Cox's Bazar Beach.[citation needed] It is a prominent landmark in Chennai.

The Marina beach was famed for its pristine beauty, jolly ambiance, and rich ecosystems. However, since the middle of the 20th century, the beach and water have become polluted. Proliferation of plastic bags, human waste, and other pollutants have rendered many parts of the beach unusable. In recent years, many voluntary organizations have taken up the task of cleaning up the Marina and protecting the ecosystem. Particular efforts include protection of olive ridley turtle nests along the Neelankarai section of the beach.

Flora and fauna

Marina Beach lies on the stretch of coast where olive ridley sea turtles, a species classified as Schedule 1 of the Indian Wildlife Protection Act of 1972 (critically endangered), nest during mating season, chiefly between late October and April peaking from mid-January to mid-February. The Ennore‚ÄìMamallapuram zone, on which the beach lies, is one of the three major nesting grounds on the Indian coast. However, with the expansion of the shrimp trawling fishery in the eastern coast of India in the mid-1970s, several individuals of the species are washed ashore dead every year. The eggs laid by the females along the beach are also sold in the local market by the fishermen and traders. In 1977, a recovery program was started by the Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute. Many volunteer organizations in the city, such as the Students' Sea Turtle Conservation Network and the Sea Turtle Protection Force of the TREE Foundation, get involved in conservation of the species along the coast.

Renowned for its golden sands and vibrant ambiance, the beach is a hub for locals and tourists alike. Visitors can enjoy leisurely walks, local food stalls, and view historical monuments along the promenade. While the beach is ideal for relaxation and recreational activities, swimming and bathing are strictly prohibited due to strong undercurrents. The surrounding area boasts significant landmarks, including the Chennai Lighthouse and several memorials, reflecting the city's rich cultural heritage.

Had a good time visiting the Anna Geology Museum and Vandalur Zoo last Sunday. It's a great place for families and kids to explore and learn about wildlife and geology. The overall experience was enjoyable, and the place is well-maintained.

However, since April is quite hot, the walking paths get really exhausting due to the high temperatures. It would be great if more trees and shaded plant areas are added along the way to give some relief from the sun.

One concern I noticed was a deer that had escaped its enclosure and was eating human-discarded food. While it was surprising to see, it also shows the need for better monitoring and care in the deer section to avoid any risks to the animals or visitors.

On the positive side, they support both cash and QR code payments, which is very convenient in this digital age. But one important suggestion: there was no clear notice or signage informing visitors that online payment can be done directly through a QR code without standing in the ticket queue. I waited in a long queue only to be told at the counter to scan and book online via WhatsApp chatbot. This needs to be highlighted with proper boards at the entrance to save visitors' time.

Despite these small issues, the zoo offers a rich and diverse experience and is definitely worth visiting. A few improvements can make it even better!

Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary is tucked away more than 12 km from the national highway, accessible via charmingly narrow roads winding through lush green fields. The journey itself feels like an adventure, leading you to this peaceful bird-watching haven.

We visited in late January and spotted only 4-5 varieties of birds, so maybe the birds started returning from vacation? That said, it's a great place for kids‚Äîthey‚Äôll enjoy the walk and the little surprises nature throws at them. The sanctuary is well-maintained, with clean walkways and seating areas. There‚Äôs one watchtower and three viewpoints spread across a 1 km stretch, offering great views of the birds.

For those hoping to get a closer look, binoculars are available for rent outside the gate at ‚Çπ100 each. However, they offer about the same clarity as your own eyes‚Äîso unless you enjoy carrying extra weight for fun, you might as well skip them!

Parking is spacious, but here‚Äôs a pro tip: If you‚Äôre thrilled to find a shady spot under a tree, brace yourself. After spending 1-2 hours inside admiring the birds, you‚Äôll return to a car that looks like a modern art piece‚Äîdecorated in a variety of bird droppings. So, don‚Äôt worry about parking in the open under the sun; at least your vehicle will be safe from "aerial attacks!"

Tickets are nominally priced and can be purchased at the entry gate. The toilets inside look clean, but there‚Äôs a catch‚Äîthey‚Äôre locked. So, if nature calls, make sure it does before you enter, or be prepared for a test of patience.

Overall, it‚Äôs a nice getaway for nature lovers, just come with realistic bird expectations, avoid shady parking spots, and maybe bring your own binoculars!

Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary is a fantastic destination for a weekend visit, especially during the current migratory bird season, which peaks from November to February. Here‚Äôs a super review based on its highlights:

üåø Overview:
Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary is one of India‚Äôs oldest bird sanctuaries, located about 75 km from Chennai, Tamil Nadu. It‚Äôs renowned for its serene environment and the large number of migratory birds that visit every year.

üïäÔ∏è Birdwatching:
During this season, you‚Äôll spot thousands of birds, including painted storks, pelicans, cormorants, spoonbills, herons, and ibises. Early mornings or late afternoons are the best times for birdwatching as the birds are most active.

üåû Ideal Time:
Weekends are perfect for a family or group outing, but try to start early to avoid crowds. The sanctuary opens from 6:00 AM to 6:00 PM. Carry binoculars for a closer view of the birds.

üì∏ Photography:
The sanctuary offers excellent opportunities for photography, with lush greenery, a large lake, and birds in their natural habitat.

üöó Accessibility:
The sanctuary is easily accessible by road. Ample parking space is available. From Chennai, the drive takes about 1.5 to 2 hours.

üç¥ Amenities:
There are a few local eateries near the sanctuary, but it‚Äôs a good idea to carry snacks and water. Basic washroom facilities are available.

üåü Pro Tips:

Bring a hat and sunscreen to protect yourself from the sun.
Avoid loud noises to not disturb the birds.
Check for weather conditions before planning your visit.
Verdict: A visit to Vedanthangal during the migratory season is a delightful experience for nature lovers and bird enthusiasts. It‚Äôs a rejuvenating escape from city life and an opportunity to connect with wildlife!
Toilets
Neat and clean

Vedanthangal place is mostly known by many people in world by this name ‚ÄúVedanthangal Bird Sanctuary‚Äù. Spread over 74 acres, it is centuries-old sanctuary has a history of once protected by local villagers to safeguard the migratory birds that nest here. It's renowned for its large number of different birds that visit every year from other countries.

It is a nice place to visit with your family. If you are planning please visit during the migratory bird season which peaks from December to till March 1st week. Well maintained & tree covered walkway. The walk inside may take an hour, if you want spend more time you can. There were some viewing areas like watch tower & some places where you can see them from some heights. Some sitting area is also available from there too you can see birds.

Here you can see these kind of migratory birds
Ibises, Painted storks, Cormorants, Spoonbills, Pelicans, Herons etc.., & you can also watch how they build their nest if you are visiting in January & boards of each birds with their specifications is place inside the  sanctuary. The staff working over there are so kind even they tell us about each & every bird &  their behaviour & which month they will hatch, from which point you can view all the birds. But you will be seeing the birds from quite a distance. So if you have binoculars carry them for clear view of the birds. Do take a good camera & a binocular if you have at your home or else you can rent a binocular for which is available outside the sanctuary for ‚Çπ50/- (single) small binocular specially for children & ‚Çπ100/-(single) for all ages.

There are a few local eateries near the sanctuary like fruits, pakoras, bhajjis, mangoes, tea & coffee , toys, coconut water, ice - creams, & some bakery item all at very reasonable prices. you can carry food, snacks & water inside the sanctuary but please don‚Äôt feed birds (or) throw those inside the water. Don‚Äôt go near the water as it some times smells bad because of the greenery in the water. You can feel like picnic inside & have some food with family & make some chit - chat. Avoid to make noises & blasting sounds birds will be frightened.

The entry price of sanctuary is ‚Çπ10/- for adult & ‚Çπ5/- for children. For Mobile ‚Çπ50/- ( Not for each Mobile ‚Çπ50/- for over all family.) & for camera ‚Çπ100/-. Wheel chairs also available on pay for the old age & disabled people. For Indians & foreigner the price level differs. The sanctuary opens for all day from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm. Early mornings or after 3:00 pm are the best times for birdwatching as the birds are most active. Parking facility is available. Restrooms are neat & tidy. Must say it's a place worth visiting for a single day trip.

Vedanthangal is a bird paradise located around 1.5 hours from Chennai, in Madurantakam in the Chengalpattu district. If you are coming from Chennai and using Google Maps, around 3 minutes before reaching the sanctuary, you are likely to come across a mud road, where you will probably wonder if you have come on the right path or if Google bro is mistaken. You may ask a local person like we did and they will probably tell you (noticed the guy rolling his eyes) to proceed on to the left. If you do, the bad road will end in around 100 metres and you will be back on the main road.
At the gate, you will need to buy reasonably priced tickets. Cameras are priced at extra Rs 50. Binoculars may be taken for rent outside the gate for Rs.100. Having a good set of powerful binoculars is very useful in the sanctuary. There is a walk of about a kilometre during which you will see a diverse variety of flora and fauna. Although known for its migratory and resident birds, one can see stunning butterflies, bees, moths, ants and if you're lucky even snakes.

There are watch towers built along the pathway, where one can climb up and get a spectacular view of the mangroves and it's feathered residents. Some of the beautiful birds that we sighted include the painted storks, pelicans, bronze winged jacana, golden oriole, pond and grey herons, owls, egrets, cormorants and darters.
When we visited, we came across some naturalists who work with the forest officials and caretakers in spreading awareness and conducting surveys.
Once the stretch is completed, we were advised by the forest rangers to turn and return the same way. Going ahead into the forest is prohibited.
Although we visited in March and still sighted several species of birds, it is recommended to visit between November end and February and reach there as early in the day as possible.

There is supposed to be a government guest house nearby which one can stay overnight and reach the sanctuary before dawn to get maximum sightings.
Vedanthangal is the oldest wildlife sanctuary in India and it's heartwarming to see it and it's feathered inhabitants being protected and cared for by genuine people, organisations and the government.

5 Star | A Fascinating Experience for Reptile Enthusiasts

Entry Fee (Feb 2025):

Snake Park: ‚Çπ30 per person

Camera/Mobile Phone Charge: ‚Çπ20 (only for Snake Park)

Iguana Interaction Zone: ‚Çπ10 per person

Parking: Charged separately

The Chennai Snake Park, established in 1972 by renowned herpetologist Romulus Whitaker, is a unique attraction in Chennai, offering visitors an up-close look at a diverse collection of reptiles.

Pros:

‚úÖ Diverse Reptile Collection ‚Äì The park houses not only various snakes (including King Cobras, pythons, and vipers) but also crocodiles, turtles, and iguanas.
‚úÖ Interactive Iguana Exhibit ‚Äì Inside the park, there's a special iguana enclosure where visitors can touch and interact with the iguanas for an additional ‚Çπ10.
‚úÖ Shaded Environment ‚Äì Unlike many outdoor attractions in Chennai, this park is well-covered with trees, making it comfortable to visit even in summer.
‚úÖ Adjacent to Guindy Children's Park ‚Äì Since it's right next to Guindy Children‚Äôs Park, you can extend your visit if you're with family or kids.
‚úÖ Washrooms Available ‚Äì Basic facilities like washrooms are present inside the park.

Cons:

‚ùå Short Visit Duration ‚Äì The park can be explored in 1.5 to 2 hours max, so it's not an all-day attraction.
‚ùå Less Crowd, Limited Buzz ‚Äì While this ensures a peaceful visit, those expecting a bustling environment might find it a bit quiet.

Overall:

The Chennai Snake Park is highly recommended for snake and nature lovers, families, and those looking for an educational yet exciting experience. The well-shaded surroundings make it a good place to visit even in summer. While it‚Äôs not a full-day attraction, it‚Äôs definitely worth a visit if you're in Chennai!

Would I recommend it? Yes, definitely!

Snake Review: "The Guindy Snake Park's incredible collection of snakes, including the majestic Indian Cobra, venomous Russell's Viper, and massive Reticulated Python, left me mesmerized and eager to learn more about these fascinating creatures."

Crocodile Review: "Getting up close and personal with the formidable crocodiles at the Guindy Snake Park was an exhilarating experience, and I applaud the park's efforts in providing a safe and natural habitat for these ancient predators."

Tortoise Review: "Watching the gentle giant tortoises roam freely and peacefully in their spacious enclosure at the Guindy Snake Park was a heartwarming experience, and a testament to the park's dedication to providing a nurturing environment for these incredible animals."

I loved exploring the handmade crafts, watching silk and mat weaving, and even got to try pottery‚Äîwhich was a fun and memorable experience. There‚Äôs also a nice restaurant, clean restrooms, and a play area for kids. It‚Äôs a perfect spot for families, art lovers, and anyone wanting a cultural break from the city. Highly recommend visiting!

Visiting the Birla Planetarium and Periyar Science and Technology Centre in Chennai was a great experience. There‚Äôs a lot to see from life-size rocket models like the GSLV and BrahMos to interactive science exhibits. The 360-degree 3D sphere show was definitely a highlight really immersive and well done. I also found the weighing machine that shows your weight on different planets pretty cool.

The human evolution section with displays on early humans and Neanderthals was interesting and there were plenty of exhibits covering space chemistry and physics. The outdoor area had some dinosaur models though a few could use some maintenance. There were also some defense and technology exhibits adding to the variety. I noticed another 3D show but I didn‚Äôt have time to check it out.

Overall it‚Äôs a great place for anyone interested in space and science. Definitely worth a visit especially for students and families

Birla Auditorium is a must-visit for students eager to learn about planets, their evolution, and functioning. The multilingual video screenings were informative and included a fascinating display of aeronautical and military vehicles. Children especially enjoyed the 3D show and interactive scientific games. I was impressed by the diverse range of vehicles showcased, with clear explanations and visuals from motorcycles to airplanes. The outdoor exhibit featured a train engine and a large aircraft. The auditorium also offers convenient amenities like a canteen, clean restrooms, and a children's play area. A valid entry ticket is required, and there's ample parking available.
